    Covalent Small Molecule Immunomodulators Targeting the Protease Active Site

    • Hong-Rae Kim
      Hong-Rae Kim
      Chemical Biology Laboratory, National Cancer Institute, Frederick, Maryland 21702, United States
      More by Hong-Rae Kim
      View Biography
      • ,

      Ravichandra Tagirasa

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Cells of the immune system utilize multiple proteases to regulate cell functions and orchestrate innate and adaptive immune responses. Dysregulated protease activities are implicated in many immune-related disorders; thus, protease inhibitors have been actively investigated for pharmaceutical development. Although historically considered challenging with concerns about toxicity, compounds that covalently modify the protease active site represent an important class of agents, emerging not only as chemical probes but also as approved drugs. Here, we provide an overview of technologies useful for the study of proteases with the focus on recent advances in chemoproteomic methods and screening platforms. By highlighting covalent inhibitors that have been designed to target immunomodulatory proteases, we identify opportunities for the development of small molecule immunomodulators.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The human immune system that comprises two mutually nonexclusive components—the innate and the adaptive immune system—protects us not only against invading pathogens but also from internal threats such as damaged cells and cancer. For optimal human health, the immune system needs to be tightly controlled and stay balanced. In fact, immune dysregulation is central to many disease-associated conditions, such as inflammation, autoimmune disorders, neurodegeneration, infection, and cancer. Immunomodulators are a diverse array of natural, recombinant, and synthetic agents that act at different cellular and molecular levels of the immune system. By modulating immune response to a desired level, as in immunostimulants or immunosuppressants, immunotherapeutic agents provide an avenue for prophylactic or chronic disease control.(1) Different types of therapeutics have been developed to activate or inhibit specific populations of immune cells and selectively target the signaling pathways engaged in immune regulation.(2−4) Recently, the field of tumor immunology has gained a tremendous amount of momentum owing to the success of novel cancer immunotherapies. Most of these medicines are monoclonal antibodies blocking interactions between T cell checkpoint receptors and their cognate ligands (e.g., PD-1, PD-L1, and CTLA-4).(5,6) Genetically engineered T cell therapies have also shown significant clinical outcomes in hematological cancers.(7) These breakthroughs have led to a growing interest in developing novel immunotherapy agents. Small molecule immunomodulators, in particular, that are complementary to or potentially synergistic with the biologics or target defined pathways inaccessible to the biologics have the potential to offer rational, target- and mechanism-guided approaches and fulfill an unmet medical need in immunotherapy.
    Proteases are essential players in a multitude of biological processes, including cell growth and death, signal transduction, and homeostasis through their diverse functions in protein maturation, degradation, and post-translational modification. Proteases control several key functions of innate and adaptive immune cells.(8) Acting as enzymes and/or adapter proteins, proteases regulate dynamic immune cell signaling.(9) Endolysosomal proteases play vital roles in antigen processing and presentation. Many proteases are required for immune cell differentiation and development, cytokine regulation, and initiation and execution of apoptosis. Due to their irreversible nature, unlike most other post-translational modifications, proteolytic activity is highly regulated through multiple mechanisms. Most proteases are expressed as inactive zymogens and become active through proteolysis, cofactor binding, post-translational modification, conformational alteration, or changes in localization. Once it is activated, the protease activity is also controlled by the presence of endogenous protein inhibitors and degradation. Therefore, measures of activity in addition to abundance are necessary for the study of proteases. To dissect their complex roles and identify their substrates in a biologically relevant context, the development of highly selective probes is crucial given the functional redundancy of proteases.
    Small molecule modulators that bind selectively to target proteins serve not only as tools to understand the protein function but also as leads in drug discovery. While most small molecules function by interacting with their biological targets under equilibrium binding conditions, ligands that chemically modify proteins through covalent bond formation can offer potential advantages that include improved ligand potency, prolonged duration of action, increased ability to overcome resistant mutations, and capability to facilitate identification of target proteins. Compounds that properly combine the features of chemical reactivity and molecular recognition can have a better chance of tackling proteins that are considered undruggable. Covalent chemical probes have been widely used in imaging, proteome-wide target identification, and inhibitor development. Covalent ligands can target either catalytically essential residues, for example, cysteine and serine in hydrolases, or noncatalytic residues found in small molecule binding sites on kinases. Depending on the electrophile and nucleophile, they bind reversibly or irreversibly. Noncovalent interactions contributed by the scaffold are critical for specificity and for positioning the reactive electrophile relative to the protein nucleophile, thereby increasing the rate, selectivity, and stability of covalent bond formation. However, it is often difficult to find an optimal recognition scaffold that is specific for a single protease because of similarities in structure and substrate preference of closely related proteases. In addition, identifying reactive functional groups that do not make the molecule promiscuous is a challenge in developing covalent modulators. Promiscuous electrophiles that readily react with nucleophiles raise concerns about toxicity and metabolic liability. Despite these obstacles, three FDA approved drugs—bortezomib, carfilzomib, and ixazomib—that covalently inhibit the proteolytic activity of proteasome have proven successful and are currently used as anticancer therapies for the treatment of multiple myeloma.(10) Understanding biochemical and structural differences between the human and parasite proteasome has also opened up an opportunity for the rational design of selective inhibitors that kill the protozoa while sparing the host.(11,12)
    This Review highlights recent advances in the development of covalent modulators targeting immune-relevant proteases. As proteases regulate essential pathways in all living organisms, pathogenic proteases are certainly viable targets for anti-infective agents. This Review, however, focuses on mammalian proteases and their roles in the initiation and regulation of immune responses. We aim to discuss lessons and opportunities for the development of covalent modulators in the field of chemical immunology by providing an overview of approaches that enable the identification of selective compounds and highlighting each application in the study of proteases.

    Approaches to Protease Probe Discovery

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Advances in combinatorial library synthesis, structural biology, computational modeling, and high-throughput screening (HTS) have facilitated the discovery of protease inhibitors and helped study the complex roles of proteases. The classical, target-centric approach begins with target selection, which is inspired by genetic and/or biochemical information that provides insight about a biological function of the protein (Figure 1A). Once a target is chosen, an appropriate assay that measures the protein activity is developed. For example, enzyme assays using fluorogenic substrates are commonly implemented to monitor the protease activity owing to their easy access and suitability for HTS. Compounds are screened and subsequently optimized through medicinal chemistry with the focus on potency and selectivity, which ultimately yields a hit compound that can be used in cell and/or animal models for functional study to further validate the target perturbation and phenotypic outcome. Often, this approach faces issues of in vivo efficacy and toxicity later in the process, possibly because this approach can overestimate the impact of pharmacological perturbation of individual proteases and lack a clear understanding of in vivo off-target effects. On the other hand, the chemocentric approach emphasizes identifying a hit compound that exerts an effect in a more complex and biological context where the protein remains in its native environment. This alleviates the need for recombinant expression and purification of protein in an early stage of screening and places pharmacology at the front (Figure 1B). This approach is not biased toward a specific target protein and proceeds without a prior knowledge of compound–protein interactions as long as a specific and measurable biological effect is produced. Once a biologically active compound is identified, advanced technologies are required to identify target proteins that interact with the compound. As this approach can yield probes that have multiple targets, understanding precise mechanism of action might be challenging although target promiscuity can be advantageous for tackling related proteins that function together in important biological pathways.
    A chemoproteomic platform termed activity-based protein profiling (ABPP) has been a valuable strategy to develop selective inhibitors against many protease targets.(13) ABPP uses covalent probes termed activity-based probes (ABPs) to map proteome-wide reactive proteins and evaluate the functional states of enzymes. In contrast to substrate-based probes that bind in the active site and produce a measurable signal upon processing by a protease (e.g., fluorogenic substrates or internally quenched fluorescent peptide substrates), ABPs remain covalently conjugated to the active site thereby inactivating the enzyme. Determined by active-site accessibility and reactivity of nucleophilic residues, probe labeling can dictate how dynamically proteins are regulated within the cell. Probe labeling can be used to substitute for the substrate assays and enable the analysis for poorly characterized enzymes that lack known substrates. Activity-based probes exploit a variety of chemical scaffolds, such as protein-reactive natural products, mechanism-based inhibitors, and electrophilic fragments. Most ABPs consist of three major components: a reactive group (an electrophilic warhead that reacts with a nucleophilic amino acid in the active site to form a covalent adduct), a recognition motif that directs to a desired protein, and a reporter tag (generally a fluorescent dye and/or an affinity handle). Each of these components needs to be carefully chosen to target the protein of interest and to be detected by an optimized assay platform. By targeting active sites, ABPP measures protease activity independently of expression and accounts for multiple layers of protease regulation. ABPP has been successfully used for comparative and spatiotemporal profiling of protease activity in disease-associated conditions and in functional proteomics studies. Competitive ABPP can be implemented to screen inhibitors directly in native proteomes or biological systems and has been particularly useful for simultaneously evaluating efficacy and selectivity of irreversible inhibitors against numerous enzymes (Figure 1C). Depending on a reporter tag appended to ABPs, probe labeling can be read out with different detection methods available. Using fluorophore-conjugated ABPs, probe-modified proteases are visualized and analyzed by sodium dodecyl sulfate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) followed by in-gel fluorescence scanning. Active proteases are also measured by fluorescent microscopy, flow cytometry, and in vivo imaging using fluorescently tagged probes. However, the fluorescent spectral overlap of commonly used fluorophores in fluorescent ABPs limits multiplex analysis of enzymes to some extent. Recently, Poreba and coworkers employed the stable isotopes of lanthanide metals compatible with mass cytometry as reporter groups.(14) With the selective peptide recognition sequences incorporated, the time-of-flight activity-based probes (TOF-probes) were able to simultaneously measure the activity of multiple proteases, including cathepsin B and L, legumain, and neutrophil elastase in various subpopulations of human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs). Combined with the power of CyTOF, metal-mass tagged ABPs thus provide a strategy for multiplexed profiling of protease activities. ABPs with a biotin tag can be employed for enrichment, identification, and quantitative analysis of probe-labeled proteins using liquid chromatography mass spectrometry (LC-MS) methods. One example of quantitative protein profiling in the proteome is the isotopic tandem orthogonal proteolysis-activity-based protein profiling (isoTOP-ABPP).(15) In a competitive isoTOP-ABPP, cells or cell lysates are treated first with either a covalent compound or control vehicle, respectively (Figure 1D).(16) The samples are then labeled with a probe targeting reactive amino acids within proteins followed by subsequent capturing using click chemistry with biotinylated, isotopically differentiated tags. Compounds that bind to the protein with high affinity block the site for probe labeling. After mixing control and compound-treated samples, probe-labeled proteins are enriched on the streptavidin resin. The bound proteins are subjected to sequential digestions, and the eluted peptides are analyzed by LC-MS/MS. Liganded sites are defined with amino acid residues that exhibit changes in MS chromatographic peak area comparing the compound-treated and control samples. Competitive isoTOP-ABPP coupled with fragment-based ligand discovery can rapidly discover ligandable protein sites by covalent small molecules.(17) Chemical proteomic screening of electrophilic small molecules using isoTOP-ABPP method in primary human T cells has successfully identified several compound–cysteine interactions that impair T cell activation through distinct mechanisms.(18)

    Design of Active Site Targeted Protease Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Proteases bind to their substrates through hydrogen bond, hydrophobic, and electrostatic interactions within the active site. A sequence of amino acids directly adjacent to the scissile bond is most critical for the substrate recognition (Figure 2A). Endopeptidases cleave peptide bonds in the middle of a protein, while exopeptidases cleave off one or two terminal amino acids. Proteases are generally categorized into seven distinct groups—cysteine, serine, threonine, aspartate, glutamate, metalloproteases, and asparagine peptide lyases—based on their catalytic mechanism. Nucleophilic residues in the active site of cysteine, serine, and threonine proteases directly attack and break the peptide bonds within proteins, whereas aspartyl, glutamyl, and metalloproteases use water molecules activated by the active site residues to hydrolyze the peptide bonds.
    Despite remarkable breakthroughs in developing allosteric inhibitors, most protease inhibitors that are clinically in use or in development are competitive inhibitors. By binding to the protease, usually at the active site, these inhibitors limit the formation of enzyme–substrate complex, which results in decreased product formation. The efficacy of small molecule inhibitors is dependent both on thermodynamics and kinetics of drug–target interactions. In noncovalent reversible inhibition, potency is normally used as a descriptor of the affinity of a compound. Given that the interaction of compound with its target leads to a biological response, optimization is often focused to maximize the strength of these noncovalent molecular interactions quantified by a decrease in the Kd or IC50 value. Drug–target residence time (1/koff) plays an important role in the efficacy of compound.(19) A reversible inhibitor with a very slow off rate kinetic shows prolonged interaction with its target mimicking a covalent inhibitor.(20) In covalent inhibition, overall inhibition is determined by an initial binding and the subsequent covalent modification of the protein. Parameters such as Ki that describes the noncovalent binding affinity and kinact that describes the kinetics of covalent modification are used to dissect the contributions of each to inhibition (Figure 2B). The reversibility of covalent inhibitors are measured upon dialysis, competition with excess substrate, or extended incubation time. In covalent reversible inhibition, subsequent bond cleavage decreases the duration of inhibition and lowers affinity. This mitigates some of the potential liabilities associated with the formation of irreversible adducts. Although irreversible modification of protein inherits some disadvantages, irreversible covalent inhibitors have the benefit of long-lasting even after the concentration of compound in solution decreases and are amenable to direct isolation and identification of target proteins. This ability has facilitated protease discovery, assignment of functional roles of closely related enzymes, and assessment of potential off-targets of compounds.
    For covalent modifiers, electrophiles are chosen based on the reactivity of nucleophilic residue of the target protease. For example, electrophiles in cysteine protease inhibitors are softer than those in serine and threonine protease inhibitors as the sulfhydryl group in the active site of cysteine proteases is more soft or polarizable than the hydroxyl group in the active site of serine and threonine proteases. The reactivity of electrophile is important to achieve desired selectivity. Highly reactive electrophile with increased kinact value can cancel out the effect of recognition motif and lead to significant off-target modification. On the other hand, a slow covalent bond formation by less reactive electrophile increases the contribution of molecular scaffold to the compound specificity determined by Ki value. If the covalent inactivation is too slow, it may result in overall inefficient labeling. Pharmacokinetic properties and ease of synthesis are also important factors to consider when choosing electrophiles. Examples of electrophilic warheads used in protease inhibitors are discussed in detail in the following sections.
    A peptide sequence that is derived from the sequence of an optimal substrate is most often used as the recognition element for designing active site targeted protease inhibitors. Recent advances in substrate screening methods have accelerated identification of recognition motifs that are specific enough to discriminate between closely related proteases. Multiplex substrate profiling by mass spectrometry (MSP-MS) approach compares the LC-MS/MS traces of a library of synthetic peptides that is designed to broadly cover potential substrate cleavage sites, with and without a given protease of interest.(21) Analysis of peptide fragments reveals the cleavage sites and amino acid residue preferences for the protease (Figure 3A). Positional scanning substrate combinatorial libraries (PS-SCL) uses isokinetic mixtures of natural amino acids except at the investigated position of the substrate for synthesis, thus providing exhaustive coverage of potential substrates. Proteolytic events can be detected by fluorescent signals (e.g., 7-amino-4-methylcoumarin) that are produced upon cleavage of substrate. This method allows rapid profiling of amino acid specificity.(22−24) To explore larger sequence space and identify motifs that are more selective, hybrid combinatorial substrate library (HyCoSuL) uses both natural and non-natural amino acids at the investigated position (Figure 3B).(25,26) Fluorogenic peptide substrate microarrays display peptides on a solid surface, which allows a quick analysis of data through direct scanning of the microarray slide with minimal usage of sample (Figure 3C).(27,28) Substrate activity screening (SAS) uses fragment-based substrate libraries to uncover nonpeptidic building blocks. The identified building blocks are sequentially built into small molecules that can be efficiently recognized by the given protease (Figure 3D).(29,30) To overcome limitations of chemically synthesized libraries and rapidly screen larger and more diverse sequence pools, biological tools have been explored. For substrate phage display, perhaps the best utilized technique, degenerated DNA sequences encoding randomized peptides are fused with the pIII gene (Figure 3E).(31) As a result, billions of peptides with much higher diversity are produced on the phage surface with their genetic information. The library is then immobilized to an affinity support and subjected to the protease cleavage. Optimal peptide sequences can be propagated and enriched over multiple rounds of selection. The recently reported method that employs two genetically encoded substrate phage display libraries coupled with next generation sequencing (SPD-NGS) is proven to be rapid and comprehensive allowing deeper substrate coverage compared to traditional synthetic peptide libraries.(32) Additionally, phage display can be used to express diverse peptides that contain constant cysteines with variable spacer residues. Chemical linking of cysteine residues generates monocyclic or bicyclic peptides on the phage surface, in which higher specificity and stability can be attributed to the rigidity of cyclic scaffold.(33) In a recent study from the Bogyo laboratory, a phage display-based method was used to produce cyclic peptides that bind to protein targets through irreversible covalent bond formation.(34) Using a reactive linker that is capable of forming cyclic peptides and simultaneously introducing an electrophilic warhead, the study yielded highly potent and selective covalent inhibitors for a cysteine protease and a serine hydrolase.
    Based on the notion that peptidic inhibitors tend to suffer from poor pharmacological properties, approaches that focus on identifying nonpeptidic scaffolds have also been actively pursued for the protease drug development. These campaigns mostly utilize high-throughput screening, fragment-based ligand library, and structure-aided drug design to identify molecular scaffolds with drug-likeness.(35) Once a promising scaffold is successfully identified, iterative optimization process is followed to develop potent drug leads.(36)
    In the following sections, we discuss key proteases in the immune system in which covalent probes generated have helped assign biological functions to the protease in physiological and disease states and highlight compounds with potential immunomodulatory activity that best illustrate each application (Table 1).
    Table 1. Proteases with Potential Immunomodulatory Activity and Representative Covalent Compounds Targeting the Protease Active Site
    proteasecatalytic residuefunctiondiseasecompound
    caspase   Z-VAD-FMK, emricasan
    caspase-1Cys285inflammationmultiple sclerosis, rheumatoid arthritisAc-WEHD-CHO, AWP28, pralnacasan, belnacasan
    caspase-3Cys163apoptosiscancer, neurodegenerative disorderAc-DEVD-CHO, AB50, WC-II-89, Ac-CV3-AOMK, Ac-DW3-KE, Ac-ATS010-KE, bMP-3.01
    caspase-8Cys360apoptosis, T cell activation and expansioncancer, neurodegenerative disorderAc-IETD-CHO, CV8/9-AOMK, zVAD-isoPht-Trp, compound 7, 63-R
    MALT1Cys464lymphocyte activationlymphomaZ-VPRP-FMK, 4-Br-Ph-VPR-FMK, LE40, LE42, BODIPY-LVPipR-AOMK, PKG105, MI-2
    calpain 1/2Cys105/Cys285inflammationmuscular dystrophy, Alzheimer’s diseaseDCG-04, SJA6017, BDA-410, AK295, A-705239, alicapistat
    cathepsin   CA-074, JPM-OEt, LVHS, GB111-NH2, BMV109
    cathepsin KCys139bone remodeling, TLR signalingosteoporosis, osteoarthritisbalicatib, odanacatib, ONO-5334

    DPP4Ser630T cell activationautoimmune diabetes, cancervildagliptin, saxagliptin, Val-boroPro
    immunoproteasomeThr1antigen processing and presentation, inflammation, T cell differentiationsystemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, cancerUK-101, KZR-504, IPSI-001, ML604440, ONX-0914, KZR-616

    Caspase

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Caspases belong to a family of cysteine proteases playing central roles in apoptosis and inflammation. As the name cysteine dependent aspartate-specific protease indicates, caspases catalyze the protein hydrolysis through a conserved cysteine nucleophile with high specificity for cleaving after aspartate residues on the C-terminal side (P1 Asp) of substrates. Caspases are classified into “apoptotic” and “inflammatory” subgroups. Nonapoptotic, inflammatory members such as caspases-1, -4, -5, -11, and -12 are involved in processing and release of proinflammatory cytokines. Inflammasomes are multiprotein complexes that assemble in response to endogenous and exogenous insults and mediate activation of caspase-1. Upon detection of stimulus, a sensor protein oligomerizes with the scaffolding protein ASC, which recruits and activates procaspase-1 into its tetrameric form. Active caspase-1 mediates cleavage of proinflammatory cytokines interleukin (IL)-1β and IL-18 as well as gasdermin D (GSDMD) to induce inflammation and pyroptosis, which is an inflammatory form of programmed cell death accompanied by cell membrane pore formation that causes cellular swelling, membrane rupture, and release of intracellular contents.(37) Caspase-1/inflammasome complex regulates multiple processes including antimicrobial host defense, tissue repair, tumorigenesis, and metabolism and has been implicated in numerous inflammatory and autoimmune diseases.(38,39) Within the apoptotic subgroup, caspases-2, -8, -9, and -10 initiate the cascade and caspase-3, -6, and -7 execute apoptosis. Other proteases, such as cathepsins, calpains, and granzymes, can also trigger the activation of effector caspases. Caspase-mediated apoptosis also plays an important role in maintaining lymphocyte homeostasis.(40) Besides their well-characterized role in apoptosis, most apoptotic caspases have nonapoptotic role(s), and recent studies have shown their involvement in a vast array of cellular processes and regulatory mechanisms, particularly in the immune system.(41) Caspase-8 is essential for lymphocyte activation and differentiation and is required for the activation of NF-κB signaling.(42,43) Deletion of caspase-8 is found to reduce the activation of dendritic cells (DC), macrophages, and B cells.(44,45) Absent or defective caspase-10 activity is known to contribute to autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome (ALPS).(46) Caspase-3 activity is also linked to T cell activation and proliferation.(47)
    Many commonly used caspase inhibitors consist of tetrapeptide or tripeptide, in which the cleavage sequence derived from the natural substrates is coupled to an electrophilic warhead. These compounds include tetrapeptide aldehydes (e.g., Ac-WEHD-CHO (1), Ac-DEVD-CHO (2), Ac-IETD-CHO (3), Figure 4A) and activated ketones such as halomethyl ketones and acyloxymethyl ketones. A peptide inhibitor Z-VAD-FMK (4), which was designed based on the specificity profile of nine human caspases, displayed a potent and broad spectrum of caspase inhibitory activity, except for caspase-2.(48) Evolved from the early tetrapeptide leads, a series of oxamyl dipeptides was optimized for pan-caspase inhibition. Among them, emricasan (also known as IDN-6556, 5) that has antiapoptotic and anti-inflammatory effects, is the first irreversible pan-caspase inhibitor to enter clinical development and has received orphan drug status by the FDA for the treatment of liver diseases.(49)
    Given its central role in converting pro-IL-1β and pro-IL-18 into their active forms of IL-1β and IL-18, efforts to investigate caspase-1 as a therapeutic target emerged in the early 1990s. Initial approach primarily focused on utilizing the Tyr-Val-His-Asp (YVHD) sequence derived from the cleavage site of the natural substrate pro-IL-1β.(50,51) Structure–activity relationship (SAR) studies revealed that the P2 position can tolerate substitutions well, and improved Vmax/Km value was observed when the histidine residue was replaced with alanine, which yielded a reversible covalent inhibitor Ac-YVAD-CHO (also known as L-709,049).(52) Later, PS-SCL discovered that the WEHD sequence, both in a fluorogenic AMC substrate and an aldehyde inhibitor, is more preferable for caspase-1 as it showed significantly improved binding affinity (14-fold) and catalytic turnover (50-fold).(53) Continuous efforts to optimize the P2–P4 residues and reduce the peptide characteristics led to the identification of novel inhibitors pralnacasan (VX-740, 6)(54) and belnacasan (VX-765, 7)(55) in a prodrug form. The aldehyde warhead and the essential P1 Asp are tied as 5-ethoxydihydrofuran-2(3H)-one moiety, which upon cleavage by plasma and/or liver esterase releases its active compounds. Their high selectivity combined with drastically improved bioavailability advanced the compounds to clinical trials for rheumatoid arthritis (discontinued due to toxicological issues).(56) By inhibiting caspase-1, belnacasan has been shown to block the inflammasome signaling, reduce cytokine-associated neurotoxicity, and prevent GSDMD-mediated pyroptosis in both myeloid cells and oligodendrocytes, resulting in tissue preservation and improved disease outcome in models of multiple sclerosis.(57) A nitrile analogue of belnacasan replacing the aldehyde warhead showed an increase in potency for caspase-1 as well as selectivity over other caspases, especially against caspase-14, which demonstrates that the type of warhead not only influences reactivity but also contributes to selectivity. A fluorescent activity-based probe AWP28 (8) that features an acyloxymethyl ketone (AOMK) electrophile attached to an optimized recognition scaffold for caspase-1 (Tyr-Tle-Pro-Asp) was developed to characterize the inflammasome-mediated caspase-1 activation.(58) With 10-fold selectivity for caspase-1 over other caspases, the probe was able to label the ASC foci. When applied to Salmonella typhimurium-infected macrophages, the probe detected active forms of caspase-1, which was lost over time as cells underwent pyroptosis. In the absence of inflammasome-mediated caspase-1 activation, however, active caspases-3 and -7 were robustly labeled by the probe, indicating that caspase-1 activity is required to suppress apoptosis in favor of proinflammatory pyroptotic cell death upon Salmonella infection.
    PS-SCL also identified an optimal tetrapeptide sequence DEVD for apoptotic caspase-3/7.(24) Powers and coworkers have demonstrated that the peptide analogues with aza-aspartic acid (AAsp) at the P1 position equipped with a variety of epoxide warheads could not only achieve caspase selectivity over other proteases but also gain selectivity within a caspase family.(59) For instance, Z-DEV-AAsp-(S,S)-EP-COOEt (9) showed significantly higher inhibition rate for caspase-3 over caspase-1 (91-fold), caspase-6 (197-fold), and caspase-8 (11-fold) without inhibiting other cysteine and serine proteases such as papain, cathepsin B, chymotrypsin, and granzyme B. Although optimal for caspase-3/7, the DEVD sequence is also efficiently recognized by cathepsins and legumain.(60) In an effort to develop molecular imaging probes for apoptosis, specifically targeting caspases, the Bogyo group developed an ABP containing the EPD-AOMK tagged with the Cy5 fluorophore (AB50-Cy5, 10).(61) The probe labeled caspase-3 and legumain without detectable labeling of cathepsin B. To further increase cellular uptake, the cell penetrating peptide trans-activating transcriptional activator (Tat) was incorporated into the probe. When used in the thymi of mice treated with dexamethasone and in tumor-bearing mice treated with the apoptosis-inducing monoclonal antibody, the probe provided direct measurements of apoptosis. Recently, Wolan and coworkers employed unnatural amino acids into the tetrapeptide sequence to improve caspase-3 selectivity. Combined with an AOMK warhead, a pentapeptide sequence 3 Pal-Asp-βhLeu-hLeu-Asp termed CV3 (12) exhibited comparable efficacy to Ac-DEVD-CHO, while maintaining substantial selectivity for caspase-3 over caspase-7.(62) Also, CV3-AOMK equipped with biotin or 5(6)-carboxyfluorescein (FAM) reporter tag was proven to be superior to its corresponding DEVD ABPs. To further resolve the cross-reactivity with caspase-8, 24 different warheads were screened. Among, 5-methyl-2-thiophene ketoester (KE) appeared to enhance both potency and selectivity.(63) X-ray cocrystal structures of CV3 series bound to caspase-3, -7, and -8 provided detailed information on the structural basis for specificity, which eventually led to the replacement of the P2 homoleucine to phenylalanine. A pentapeptide inhibitor Ac-3 Pal-Asp-βhLeu-Phe-Asp-KE (also reported as Ac-DW3-KE) showed a remarkable selectivity profile against caspase-7 (118-fold) and caspase-8 (58-fold). However, DW3 inhibitor was not able to block staurosporine (STS)-induced apoptosis, partially due to poorer kinetic efficiency, indicating its slow caspase-3 inhibition. Structure analyses revealed that both CV3 and DW3 inhibitors had distorted peptide backbone orientations in respect to DEVD inhibitor when bound. After the P3 βhLeu was replaced with pentafluorophenylalanine (Phe(F5)), the inhibitor (Ac-ATS-010-KE, 13) showed sufficient kinetic and selectivity profiles and was able to prevent MegaFasL-induced apoptosis in Jurkat cells.(64) Poreba and coworkers have also demonstrated the successful use of unnatural amino acids for selective caspase inhibitor discovery. Instead of introducing single amino acid substitutions individually at each position of the canonical caspase substrate sequence, they used a large-scale, hybrid combinatorial substrate library (HyCoSuL) approach.(65) Selective substrates identified for apoptotic caspases-3/7, -8, -9, and -10 were subsequently converted into ABPs utilizing the AOMK warhead. Overall, catalytic parameters were well correlated between ABPs and substrates. For example, biotin-ahx-Asp-Phe(F5)-Val-Asp-AOMK (bMP-3.01) was identified as a potent and selective inhibitor of caspase 3/7. However, the conversion of substrates into ABPs resulted in significant loss of selectivity. When examined in TRAIL-stimulated Jurkat T cells, individual probes could not label each caspase specifically due to overwhelming activity and concentration of caspases-3 and -7 in cells. Although it was not possible to define an ABP that can measure activity of individual caspases in complex mixtures, the authors were able to investigate TRAIL-induced apoptotic mechanism with a panel of ABPs. Continuous efforts using HyCoSuL have also yielded a highly selective caspase-2 inhibitor. The champion compound NH-23-C2 (14) inhibited MDM-2 cleavage in a concentration-dependent manner, while preventing TRAIL-mediated apoptosis in caspase-2-induced HCT116 colon cancer cells. The selectivity of the compound can be attributed to the P4 hGlu residue, which is poorly recognized by caspase-3 despite the structural similarity of the S4 pocket and the P5 Idc residue because caspase-2 has a unique feature that prefers pentapeptides to tetrapeptides for efficient catalysis.(66)
    Although commonly used as caspase-8 inhibitors, Ac-IETD-CHO and Ac-LETD-AOMK are known to be promiscuous, particularly toward caspase-6 and -9.(24) The strategy incorporating unnatural amino acids identified H2N-βAla-Leu-Gln-Hyp-Asp sequence termed CV8/9.(67) CV8/9-AOMK (15) is not as potent as Ac-LETD-AOMK; however, drastic improvement in caspase-8 selectivity over executioner caspases-3, -6, and -7 was accomplished. The change in warhead from AOMK to KE brought further enhancement in selectivity against caspase-9. While most of protease inhibitors target nonprimed region of the active site, the primed site can also be explored using inhibitors. Groborz et al. installed iso- and tere-isomers of phthalic acid as a spacer to access the prime region of the active site.(68) Despite having a broad-spectrum caspase peptide z-VAD as the recognition motif on the nonprimed site, a single natural amino acid extension through a phthalic acid spacer was sufficient to gain selectivity within the caspases. For example, zVAD-isoPht-Trp (16) was found to be 9.5- and 19-fold more potent for caspase-8 over caspase-9 and -10, respectively. The authors were also able to develop selective inhibitors for caspase-9 (zVAD-terePht-Ser, 17) and caspase-10 (zVAD-terePht-Tyr, 18). Through a quantitative analysis of cysteine-reactive small molecule fragments screened in human proteomes, the Cravatt laboratory recently discovered covalent ligands that react preferentially with pro-forms of caspase-8 and caspase-10.(17) These compounds (19 and 20) were used to study extrinsic apoptosis pathways in primary human T cells and showed that inhibition of both caspase-8 and caspase-10 was required to suppress apoptosis in primary human T cells, while selective inhibition of caspase-8 by 63-R (20) was sufficient to block FasL-induced apoptosis in Jurkat cells, supporting that caspase-10 has important functions in primary human T cells and offering pro-caspase inhibitors as an alternative strategy in caspase inhibitor discovery.
    Among small and nonpeptidic caspase inhibitors explored, the isatin moiety that acts as an alkylating agent has been an attractive starting point because it can be easily extended or modified. A tetrahedral intermediate is formed upon nucleophilic attack of cysteine residue to the carbonyl group of the isatin. The pyrrolidine ring interacts with hydrophobic residues in the S2 pocket, which is a unique feature in caspase-3 and -7.(69) Following optimization led to the development of isotopically labeled isatin sulfonamide, [18F]WC-II-89 (11) that can be used to measure and image apoptosis in an animal model with positron emission tomography (PET).(70)
    Recently, Chakrabarty and Verhelst developed photocaged caspase inhibitors, representing novel chemical tools for the study of apoptosis in space- and time-controlled manner (Figure 4B).(71) Through a combination of the VAD or DEVD sequence with the photoprotecting group nitroindoline for the P1 aspartate, the photoactivatable derivatives were able to inhibit not only caspases in complex proteomes but also cellular apoptosis with an efficient turn-on of inhibitory activity after irradiation with light.

    MALT1

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The paracaspase Mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma translocation 1 (MALT1) belongs to a caspase family but prefers cleaving after the P1 arginine instead of aspartic acid. It has emerged as an important player in both innate and adaptive immune cells. MALT1 is involved in the activation and proliferation of lymphocytes and other immune cells such as myeloid cells, mast cells, and natural killer (NK) cells.(72) As a part of the CARMA1-BCL10-MALT1 (CBM) complex, MALT1 transduces signals from immune receptors such as B and T cell receptors toward NF-κB activation (Figure 5A).(73,74) As a protease, MALT1 cleaves specific substrates that are mainly involved in regulation of immune responses, including TNFAIP3 (A20), BCL10, CYLD, HOIL1, RelB, regnase-1, and Roquin1/2. It also functions as a scaffolding protein, where it recruits TNF receptor-associated factor 6 (TRAF6), which in turn activates TGF-β-activated kinase 1 (TAK1) and IKK complex.(75,76) In addition, MALT1 is associated with NF-κB regulation downstream of some G-protein coupled receptors or the epidermal growth factor receptor expressed by nonimmune cells.(77) An oncogenic fusion of the cellular inhibitor of apoptosis 2 (cIAP2, also known as AIP2) with MALT1 (cIAP2-MALT1), which occurs in MALT lymphoma of different sites with varying frequencies, has been reported to cleave NF-κB-inducing kinase (NIK).(78) Patients with MALT1 mutation present the combined immunodeficiency (CID) characterized by severe and recurrent bacterial, fungal, and viral infections and impaired T cell activation with abnormal cellular and humoral immune responses despite normal lymphocyte counts. Constitutively active MALT1 has been found in lymphomas such as activated B cell-like diffuse large B cell lymphoma (ABC-DLBCL), MALT lymphoma, and mantle cell lymphoma.(79) A recent study with mice expressing catalytically inactive MALT1 showed that MALT1 activity is required for maintaining homeostasis and function of regulatory T (Treg) cells that prevent autoimmunity.(80) MALT1 proteolytic activity is also necessary for optimal T helper cell 17 (Th17) differentiation and granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) production by Th17 cells.(81) Therefore, therapeutic intervention of MALT1 protease activity has been considered as a promising approach for treating lymphomas and other autoimmune and inflammatory disorders.
    The first MALT1 inhibitor was derived from the optimal tetrapeptide substrate of the Arabidopsis thaliana metacaspase AtmC9, Z-VRPR.(72,82) Through the electrophilic fluoromethyl ketone (FMK) warhead, the compound (21, Figure 5B) irreversibly inhibits MALT1, which resulted in inhibition of T cell activation and IL-2 secretion in Jurkat cells and in human antigen specific cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs). Z-VRPR-FMK treatment preferentially reduced the viability of cell lines derived from ABC-DLBCL.(79) A tripeptide analogue Z-VPR-FMK showed comparable in vitro potency but lost some cellular efficacy.(83,84) Further optimization yielded 4-bromo-benzamide derivative (22) that is 10- and 100-fold more potent in vitro and in vivo, respectively. The inhibitor treatment downregulated IL-10 expression and IL-10- and Janus kinase (JAK)-/signal transducer and activator of transcription (STAT)-related transcriptional signatures. MALT1 inhibition by 4-Br-Ph-VPR-FMK also led to upregulation of type I IFNs and MHC class II and IL-12 signaling.(84)
    Derived from the RelB substrate sequence LVSR and the BCL1 substrate sequence LRSR, the first generation of MALT1 ABPs—Cy5-LVSR-AOMK (LE40),(85) biotin-LVSR-AOMK (LE42, 23),(85) and BODIPY-LRSR-AOMK(86)—that effectively differentiate between active and inactive MALT1, when using recombinant enzyme, cellular overexpression, and endogenous MALT1 in an ABC-DLBCL cell line, was developed. Based on the observation that MALT1 substrates containing pentapeptide exhibit higher activity than substrates with tetrapeptide, Kasperkiewicz et al. explored the P5 position using unnatural amino acids and identified Ac-Phe(guan)-LVPR as the most active MALT1 substrate compared with the Ac-ALVSR substrate.(87) Equipped with the Cy5 and an AOMK, the resulting probe PKG105 selectively detected MALT1 activity in cell lysates. Additionally, using internally quenched fluorescence (IQF) substrates, it was demonstrated that MALT1 S1′ pocket is fairly restricted to glycine at the P1′ position, which agrees with the observation that cleavage of natural MALT1 substrates takes place between the P1 arginine and P1′ glycine residue. The S2′ pocket, on the other hand, is shown to have broad specificity accommodating small aliphatic amino acids and proline. More recently, Verhelst et al. developed a cell-permeable MALT1 fluorescent probe, BODIPY-LVPipR-AOMK (24), that contains pipecolinic acid in the P2 position, providing reduced cross-reactivity with cathepsin B.(88)
    From high-throughput screening (HTS), Fontan and colleagues identified compound MI-2 (25) that directly binds and irreversibly inhibits MALT1 through covalent modification of the active site Cys464 residue.(89) MI-2 was concentrated within the human ABC-DLBCL cells and inhibited cleavage of the MALT1 substrates, which was accompanied by suppression of NF-κB reporter activity, inhibition of c-REL nuclear localization, and downregulation of NF-κB target gene. MI-2 was nontoxic to mice and suppressed xenotransplant ABC-DLBCL tumors in vivo and primary human DLBCLs ex vivo.

    Calpain

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Calpains belong to a family cysteine protease with calcium-dependent activity. Within the human genome, there are 15 genes that encode calpain-like protease domain (CAPN1 to CAPN16, no CAPN4). The first described members, calpain 1 and 2 (also called μ- and m-calpain) are two most widely studied isoforms of calpain. The activation of calpains is primarily dependent on increased intracellular Ca2+ concentration(90) but some other factors may also activate calpain without calcium. For example, calpains may be activated through the extracellular signal-regulated kinases (ERKs) or mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPKs) signaling pathways. The endogenous protein inhibitor calpastatin limits the function of calpain.(91) Despite a wide variety of proteins reported as calpain substrates, including cytoskeletal and plasma membrane-associated proteins, kinases and phosphatases, membrane receptors, transporters, and transcription factors, no consensus cleavage sequence has been defined for calpains. In addition to its involvement in cell mobility and cell cycle progression, calpains have been found to be involved in protein secretion by macrophages, promotion of neutrophil recruitment, regulation of NLR family pyrin domain containing 3 (NLRP3) inflammasome, pyroptosis, and lymphocyte migration and activation. The studies indicated that calpain inhibition plays a protective role in numerous inflammation-associated diseases.(92)
    Most calpain inhibitors suffer from insufficient specificity to distinguish calpains from other proteases, partially due to lack of knowledge on the calpain substrate specificities. The first-generation calpain inhibitors include broad-spectrum cysteine protease inhibitors, E-64 (26, Figure 6) and leupeptin (Ac-LLR-CHO), originating from actinomycete and fungus, respectively.(93) Based on the E-64 scaffold, a iodinatable phenol ring and a biotinylated lysine residue were incorporated to generate the epoxide probe DCG-04 (27), which is active toward calpains and cysteine cathepsins.(94) Using DCG-04, m-calpain and related Lp82 were identified as the active cysteine proteases responsible for mediating cleavage of γ-crystalin during cataract formation in the eye lens. Aldehyde inhibitors, calpeptin (Z-Leu-Nle-CHO) and MDL28170 (Z-Val-Phe-CHO) that a hydrophobic benzyloxycarbonyl cap group was introduced instead of the terminal amino acid showed improved physicochemical characteristics. In rat models, a sulfonamide containing calpain inhibitor, SJA-6017 (28), was shown to prevent cataract formation.(95)
    Another class of reversible covalent inhibitors reported for calpain is cyclopropenone containing compounds. Possible mechanisms for the inhibition by peptidyl cyclopropenone involve the nucleophilic attack of catalytic cysteine at either of the olefinic carbons and protonation of the carbonyl oxygen yielding a stabilized aromatic hydroxycyclopropenyl cation to form charge-transfer complex. An orally bioavailable BDA-410 (29) was found to be neuroprotective in Alzheimer’s disease mouse models.(96) α-Ketoacids, α-ketoesters, and α-ketoamides, electrophiles for reversible addition, can form a tetrahedral intermediate analogue upon nucleophilic attack of the active-site cysteine residue onto the α-keto carbon. α-ketoamide inhibitor AK295 (30) showed neuroprotective effects in a rat model of cerebral focal ischemia.(97) Extensive exploration of the P3 cap group led to the identification of A-705239 (31) and A-705253 (32) with improved pharmacokinetic properties.(98) Alicapistat (ABT-957, 33)(99) developed by AbbVie had been in the clinical trials for the treatment of cognitive disorders until recently. However, it was found to be ineffective potentially due to insufficient concentration entered in the central nervous system.

    Cathepsin

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Cathepsins are major endolysosomal proteases involved in intracellular proteolysis as well as in various physiological and pathological processes. There are 15 human cathepsins which are divided into three groups depending on their active site catalytic residue: cysteine (cathepsins B, C, F, H, K, L, O, S, V, W, and X), serine (cathepsins A and G), and aspartate proteases (cathepsins D and E). Within a family of cysteine cathepsins, cathepsins S, K, V, F, and L exhibit endopeptidase activity and cathepsins B, H, X, and C exhibit both endo- and exopeptidase activity. Cathepsins have been detected not only in lysosomes but also in nuclei, cytosol, secretory vesicles, at the cell membrane, and in the extracellular space.(100) Cathepsins are transcribed as inactive zymogens in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and Golgi organelles. The prodomain blocks activity, and it becomes active either by autocatalysis under specific conditions, such as low pH or the presence of glycosaminoglycans, or through cleavage by other proteases. The activity of cathepsins is regulated by the presence of endogenous inhibitors such as cystatins, stefins, kininogens, thyropins, and serpins.
    The site- and substrate-specific activity of cathepsins regulates important biological processes, including antigen presentation, cytokine secretion, and cell differentiation and migration. Cathepsin B (CatB) has been implicated in the activation of NLRP3 inflammasomes and the production of IL-1β and tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-α.(101,102) Cathepsin K (CatK) is involved in the proteolytic activation of toll-like receptor-7 (TLR7) or TLR9.(103) Cathepsin S (CatS) also regulates the TLR signaling transduction and MHC class II-dependent CD4+ T cell activation.(104,105) CatS inhibition by leucyl-homophenylalanine-vinylsulfone (LHVS, 41, Figure 7A) caused impaired Ii processing and antigen presentation.(105) Alterations of CatS expression and activity have been found to affect antigen processing and crosstalk between immune cells in the tumor microenvironment and contribute to lymphomagenesis.(106,107) Cathepsin L (CatL) is critical for Ii processing in thymic cortical epithelial cells and positive selection of CD4+ T cells.(108) Macrophage-derived CatL activates heparanase, which is an important player in cancer, inflammatory diseases, and viral infection.(109) Recent studies have indicated that cathepsin L is required for glycoprotein processing and cleavage of the enveloped viruses, such as severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV), Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV), Ebola virus, Hendra virus, and Nipah virus, allowing them to enter the host cells and replicate.(110) A pan-cysteine protease inhibitor K11777 (37) has been shown to inhibit Ebola virus and SARS-CoV entry.(111) Cathepsin X (CatX, also known as cathepsin Z or P) is predominantly expressed in immune cells, including monocytes, macrophages, and DCs, and has been proposed to play a role in T cell activation.(112)
    Taken from the observations that cysteine cathepsins are highly upregulated in certain cancer types, cathepsins have emerged as molecular targets for the development of diagnostic tools as well as therapeutic candidates in cancer. In particular, cathepsin B and L have been implicated most in tumorigenesis. Intraperitoneal administration of CA-074 (34), which is a synthetic analogue of E-64 designed to harness the dipeptidylcarboxypeptidase activity of CatB, reduced breast cancer metastasis to bone in tumor-bearing animals, indicating that cysteine cathepsins play important roles in metastasis.(113) A cell-permeable broad-spectrum cysteine cathepsin inhibitor, JPM-OEt (35), significantly decreased tumor growth and invasiveness in a pancreatic neuroendocrine cancer model.(114) However, JPM-OEt was found ineffective for the treatment of breast cancer in a mammary gland tumor model and breast-to-bone metastasis, largely due to poor bioavailability.(115) Cathepsin inhibition with GB111-NH2 (Z-FK-AOMK, 36), which is a potent inhibitor of cathepsins B, L, and S, led to the macrophage cell death and mammary tumor regression, likely caused by increased oxidative stress in tumor-associated macrophages (TAM), which are an important class of immune cells for regulation of cancer proliferation and invasion.(116) A number of ABPs have been developed based on the Z-FK recognition motif. Particularly, fluorescently quenched ABPs (qABPs) that become fluorescent only upon specific and covalent binding to the cathepsins in an activity-dependent manner have been successfully employed for the noninvasive optical imaging of cancer. BMV109 (48, Figure 7B), bearing a tetrafluoro-substituted phenoxymethyl ketone (PMK) electrophile, displayed a greater reactivity toward CatB, S, L, and X and overall improved in vivo properties compared to previously reported AOMK-based probes. It was able to demarcate the cancer region with substantial contrast soon after the administration in a syngeneic orthotopic mouse model of breast cancer.(117) The HyCoSul-drived probe MP-cL3 (45) that features Cy5-6-ahx-His-DThr-Phe(F5)-Cys(Bzl)-AOMK showed improved activity and selectivity for CatL.(118) The probe was rapidly taken up by cells and labeled CatL with no detectable labeling of CatB up to 8 h of incubation with MDA-MB-231 cells. The same group reported an ABP for CatB (MP-CB2) containing the Cha-Leu-Glu(Bzl)-Arg sequence shortly after, which exhibited 3500-fold selectivity over CatL.(119) The Cy5-labeled MP-CB2 probe selectively labeled cathepsin B in 18 cell lines covering different types of cancer and in cells collected from stage IV nonsmall lung cancer patient.
    One major challenge, however, with targeting cathepsins is that it requires significant optimization to provide sufficient selectivity because of high homology and overlapping substrate specificity within the cathepsin family. The most common therapeutic targets among cysteine cathepsins are cathepsin K and cathepsin S with several inhibitors evaluated in different phases of clinical trials. To date, there is no CatL inhibitor entered in clinical trials, and only one CatB inhibitor (VBY-376) has completed phase I clinical study investigating the safety of single dose in healthy adults.
    Cathepsin K is highly expressed in osteoclasts and is the major protease responsible for the degradation of type I collagen, which makes up 90% of the organic bone matrix.(120) Inhibition of CatK reduces bone resorption thus, CatK inhibitors have been investigated for the treatment of bone diseases such as osteoporosis and osteoarthritis. It has been also suggested that CatK may have an important role in atherosclerosis and rheumatoid arthritis.(121,122) A study showed that CatK inhibition results in impaired TLR9 signaling in DCs in response to unmethylated CpG DNA, which in turn leads to attenuated induction of Th17 cells without affecting antigen-presenting ability.(123) For inhibitor design, a nitrile warhead that undergoes slow nucleophilic attack of enzyme to form the reversible thioimidate ester bond, has received much attention for targeting the active site of cysteine cathepsins. In the clinical study, balicatib (38), a peptidic nitrile inhibitor that potently inhibits CatK, showed increased bone mineral density and reduced bone resorption markers in the lumbar spine, femur, and hips over 18 months of treatment.(124) However, its lysosomotropic character, which accumulates the basic compound as a protonated form in acidic compartments, led to dramatically decreased selectivity in cell-based assays compared to in vitro assays.(125) Balicatib has been reported to cause skin rashes, pruritus, and rare morphea-like skin thickening,(126) potentially through the inhibition of CatB and CatL that are highly expressed in the skin and skin-derived cells. Efforts to address the side effects caused by the basic character and the metabolic liability led to the discovery of odanacatib (39).(127) Odanacatib is highly potent for reducing bone resorption markers and increasing bone mineral density.(128) However, odanacatib was discontinued while in phase III clinical trials due to increased risk of stroke in postmenopausal patients. ONO-5334 (40), an α-ketoamide inhibitor, had been in phase II clinical trials by Ono Pharmaceutical for the treatment and prevention of osteoporosis,(129) but the development was subsequently discontinued for business-related reasons.
    Cathepsin S is primarily expressed in the lysosome of antigen presenting cells (DCs, macrophages, and B cells). Upregulated production and proteolytic activity of CatS have been implicated in chronic inflammatory diseases. Given its key role in antigen presentation, CatS has been intensely explored as a therapeutic target for rheumatoid arthritis, multiple sclerosis, myasthenia gravis, psoriasis, asthma, and wound healing. The Ellman laboratory applied the substrate activity screening (SAS) method to CatS and identified 1,4-disubstituted-1,2,3-triazole-based nonpeptidic aldehyde and nitrile inhibitors that display high selectivity for cathepsin S.(30,130) Taking these nonpeptidic triazole scaffolds as a starting point, the Bogyo group developed qABPs for CatS (42 and 43). BMV083 (42) showed a high tumor-specific fluorescence when using the noninvasive optical imaging methods in a syngeneic breast cancer model.(131) The probe primarily labeled macrophages with an M2 phenotype. As M2 macrophages generally exert an immune suppressive, tumor-promoting phenotype, BMV083 may find application as a potential in vivo reporter for tumor growth. Highly selective CatS inhibitors containing pyrrolidine ring that utilizes specific ligand–protein interactions in the S2 pocket of CatS with the rigid cyclic scaffold showed favorable in vivo properties. Initial study reported that the compound reduced IL-2 production in a dose-dependent manner in a transgenic DO10.11 mouse model of antigen presentation, expressing an ovalbumin-specific T cell receptor.(132) RO5459072 (44),(133) which is a potent, selective, and orally available inhibitor of CatS, passed the phase I for celiac disease and completed the phase II studies for Sjogren’s syndrome.
    Although the protease activity of cathepsin X has been linked to activation, maturation, and migration of immune cells, its physiological roles remain poorly understood. To study biological functions of CatX both in vitro and in vivo, Paulick and coworkers have developed an ABP, MGP140 (46) that labels CatX in addition to CatB, S, and L.(134) The recently reported activity-based probe that contains a sulfoxonium ylide warhead (sCy5-Val-SY, 47) exhibited improved specificity for CatX in cell lysates, intact cells, and human tissues.(135)

    Legumain

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Legumain, or asparaginyl endopeptidase (AEP), is another cysteine protease that is mainly present in the endolysosomal system. It was first identified in legumes as a vacuolar processing enzyme with high preference for processing the substrates after P1 asparagine residues.(136) Legumain belongs to the CD clan of proteases and family C13 of cysteine proteases that share the conserved His-Gly-spacer-Ala-Cys catalytic motif. Mammalian legumain has a broad tissue distribution and is localized to different types of antigen presenting cells. Similar to cathepsins, the proteolytic activity of legumain is regulated by expression as a proenzyme, pH, and complex formation with endogenous inhibitor cystatins. The protein substrates of legumain include prolegumain itself, autoantigens such as the myelin basic protein (MBP) or the tetanus toxin C-terminal fragment (TTCF), other lysosomal proteases such as cathepsins B, H, and L and their inhibitor cystatin, TLR7/9, invariant chain chaperone Ii, protein phosphatase 2 inhibitor SET, and tau protein, that share an asparagine or aspartic acid at the P1 position. Additionally, legumain exhibits ligase activity.(137) As evidenced by its protein substrates, legumain is found to be involved in antigen processing and presentation on the MHC class II complex, TLR processing, and matrix degradation. Deregulated legumain activity has been implicated in multiple pathophysiological conditions, including inflammation, atherosclerosis, Alzheimer’s disease, and cancer. Overexpression of legumain has been reported in various solid tumors (e.g., breast, colon, lung, prostate, and ovarian cancer),(138) and upregulated legumain activity has been associated with an increase in tumor growth and metastasis and a poor prognosis for cancer patients.(139) Legumain is also highly expressed on the cell surface of tumor-associated macrophages in the tumor microenvironments.(138,140)
    Legumain is biochemically close to cysteine cathepsins. However, pan-cysteine protease inhibitor E-64 does not inhibit legumain. Legumain cleaves the substrates after asparagine residues with high level of specificity. However, when introduced in inhibitor, the amide side chain of the P1 Asn leads to intramolecular cyclization reaction with the electrophilic group and ultimately results in loss of inhibitory activity. To overcome this instability issue, a series of azaAsn inhibitors including azaAsn halomethyl ketones (e.g., 49, Figure 8), azaAsn epoxides, and azaAsn Michael acceptors has been developed and showed significantly higher stability while maintaining inhibitory potency toward mammalian legumain. A Pro-azaAsn dipeptide (LI-1, 50), in which the P2 proline was incorporated to reduce the cross-reactivity toward other cysteine proteases, has been reported as a potent legumain inhibitor.(141)
    A series of legumain inhibitors that utilizes a nitrile electrophilic warhead was discovered by the Williams group.(142,143) The increase in inhibitory potency observed by the extension of P3 position with a biphenyl ring (51) suggested that the S3 pocket of legumain can well accommodate bulky and hydrophobic moieties. However, the inhibitor displayed low solubility and metabolic instability, preventing in vivo applications.
    Because legumain is also able to hydrolyze the substrates after P1 aspartic acids when in the acidic lysosome, peptide inhibitors with the P1 Asp have been studied for legumain. Caspase inhibitors that feature the P1 Asp and halomethyl ketone warhead (e.g., Z-DEVD-CMK, Ac-YVAD-CMK, and Z-VAD-FMK) presented some cross-reactivity with legumain. A truncated, dipeptide inhibitor Ac-PD-AOMK (LI-0) was developed to minimize the off-target activity. Although more potent for legumain, the analysis of kinetics showed that the difference in inhibition between legumain and caspase-3 by LI-0 was not significant.(144) Based on the EPD-AOMK motif that targets both caspases and legumain, the Bogyo group developed a qABP.(145) Surprisingly, the probe LE28 (52) was found to be highly selective for legumain when used in whole cells and tissues. The authors attributed this specificity to the presence of hydrophobic fluorophore and quencher. Moreover, it appeared that the probe was taken up by cells and directed to endolysosomal compartments, bypassing the cytosol where caspases reside. A study reported that legumain is activated in the pancreas during caerulein-induced acute and chronic murine pancreatitis indicated by the LE28 probe labeling of legumain.(146) The activity of legumain was found to be highly correlated with macrophage activation. In another recent study, the LE28 probe detected activated legumain in oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC).(147) It showed that legumain can cleave protease-activated receptor-2 (PAR2) at a unique site and act as a novel biased PAR2 agonist to promote oral cancer pain. Accordingly, legumain inhibitor LI-1 (50) was shown to prevent OSCC pain in mice. Poreba and coworkers discovered a highly selective tetrapeptide inhibitor of legumain, DY-Tic-SD-AOMK, which was subsequently converted into a biotinylated ABP (MP-L01, 53). The probe efficiently labeled legumain in live cells without detectable cross-reactivity against cathepsins.(148)

    Deubiquitinase (DUB)

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Ubiquitination is a reversible post-translational protein modification, in which the amide bond between the C-terminal Gly residue of ubiquitin (Ub) and the lysine residue of substrate protein (or lysine on another ubiquitin) can be hydrolyzed by a family of isopeptidases known as deubiquitinases (DUBs) (Figure 9A). DUBs can be subdivided into six families: ubiquitin-specific protease (USP), ubiquitin C-terminal hydrolase (UCH), ovarian tumor domain protease, Machado–Joseph disease (MJD), motif interacting with Ub-containing novel DUB (MINDY), and JAB1/MPN/Mov34 metalloenzyme (JAMM) families. The JAMM DUBs belong to zinc metalloproteases, whereas all the other families use the nucleophilic cysteine residue to hydrolyze the isopeptidic bond. DUBs differ in their specificity for substrate as well as for ubiquitin chain types.
    DUBs play critical roles in maintaining protein homeostasis and regulating cellular trafficking and protein–protein interactions. In the adaptive immunity, DUBs have been linked to the development, activation, and differentiation of T cells and regulation of T cell tolerance. Among the members of USP family, USP4 deubiquitinates Lys63-linked polyubiquitin chains from TAK1, TRAF2 and TRAF6 negatively regulating TNFα-induced NF-κB activation.(149,150) It has been reported that USP4 is highly expressed in Th17 cells and stabilizes the nuclear receptor retinoid-related orphan receptor-γt (RORγt), promoting Th17 differentiation.(151) Its depletion or use of inhibitor also resulted in decreased expression of RORγt and IL-17A.(151,152) Moreover, CD4+ T cells from patients with rheumatic heart disease exhibited significantly elevated USP4 and IL-17 mRNA, but not RORγt mRNA, providing evidence for a role of USP4 in autoimmune diseases. USP7, one of the most widely studied DUBs, has been known to regulate numerous tumor suppressor proteins including p53 and murine double minute 2 protein (MDM2), an E3 ligase of p53, and phosphatase and tensin homologue (PTEN).(153,154) Studies also have reported that USP7 is involved in maintenance of Treg cell function. Upregulated and active USP7 found in primary Treg cells positively regulates the stability of transcription factor Foxp3, which is critical in the development and function of Treg cells.(155) USP7 also deubiquitinates and stabilizes Tip60, an essential acetyltransferase required for acetylation of histones and other nonhistone proteins. Tip60 is known to promote the acetylation-dependent dimerization of Foxp3 for maintaining Treg stability and immune tolerance.(156) Genetic ablation or pharmacologic inhibition of USP7 has been shown to impair Treg functions.(157) As Treg cells restrict the antitumor immune responses and promote tumor survival, these results suggest that specific USP7 inhibitors can promote antitumor immunity and enhance the efficacy of immunotherapeutic agents. USP9X has been found to be involved in regulation of cell survival and TGF-β signaling by deubiquitinating myeloid leukemia cell differentiation protein 1 (Mcl1), the HECT-type E3 ubiquitin ligase (E3) Itch, and Smad4.(158,159) USP9X also positively regulates T cell receptor (TCR) signaling and T cell tolerance. USP9X appears to interact with BCL10 in the CBM complex and remove ubiquitin chains from TCR-stimulated BCL10.(160) USP9X deficiency leads to expansion of antigen-experienced T cell populations and development of spontaneous lupus-like autoimmunity and lymphoproliferative disease.(161)
    ABPs that contain Cys-targeting electrophiles in place of the C-terminal Gly of ubiquitin (Figure 9B) have proven to be powerful tools to identify DUBs in a physiologically relevant context, characterize DUB enzymatic activity, and study DUB inhibitors. Ubiquitin-aldehyde (Ubal) was used to solve the first structure of a DUB in complex with Ub, which revealed the conformational changes of DUB that occur upon Ub binding.(162) Ubiquitin-vinylmethyl sulfone (Ub-VS), ubiquitin-vinylmethyl ester (Ub-VME), and ubiquitin-propargyl amide (Ub-PA) are covalently and irreversibly attached to the catalytic cysteine of DUBs. A study showed that HA-Ub-VS can distinguish between the active and inactive forms of USP9X. The catalytic activity of USP9X was shown to be enhanced by TCR-dependent phosphorylation after T cell stimulation, determined by increased labeling of USP9X by HA-Ub-VS without an increase in protein levels.(163) A propargyl amide warhead reacts via direct nucleophilic attack on the internal alkyne carbon, facilitated by stabilization of the carbanion by the oxyanion hole of the active site.
    Ubiquitin-based activity-based probes, however, lack target selectivity. To obtain a potent and selective tool for a particular DUB of interest, researchers have developed engineered Ub variants using phage display libraries or computational approaches.(164−166) The Drag laboratory recently used also the HyCoSuL approach to develop a selective ABP for DUB. Substitution for the conserved Leu-Arg-Gly-Gly motif with the selected peptide sequences, Cha-Arg-Abu-Gly or d-Arg-Phe(guan)-Ala-Gly, led to a highly active and selective ubiquitin probe that can detect UCH-L3 activity.(167) Another challenge in developing chemical probes for deubiquitinases is that unlike ABPs for many proteases where only short peptide recognition motifs are required, full-length ubiquitin is often necessary for an efficient reaction between a probe and DUBs. Many catalytic domains of apo-DUB are in catalytically inactive conformations, and ubiquitin binding often induces structural rearrangements and brings the active site residues into the correct position for catalysis. Despite this, the Tate group recently reported the first cell permeable, small molecule DUB ABP. An alkyne-tagged analogue of 4-chloroacetylpyrrole derivative (54, Figure 9C) that was discovered through HTS identified 12 USPs including USP4, USP16, and USP33 as the protein targets in osteosarcoma cells.(168)
    The therapeutic potentials of inhibiting DUBs have been actively investigated given the important roles that DUBs play in many pathophysiological processes. In particular, developing USP7 inhibitors for cancer treatment has received an increasing interest in part due to the recent demonstration that USP7 is implicated in the ability of tumors to evade surveillance and immune-mediated killing. HBX 19818 (59) was discovered by Hybrigenics from a high-throughput USP7 screen using Ub-AMC as the fluorogenic substrate. It irreversibly binds to USP7 by the nucleophilic aromatic substitution with consequent loss of the chlorine and weakly inhibits USP7 (IC50 28 μM).(169) The mechanism of covalent modification by this activated aromatic chlorine through a tetrahydroacridine system may be similar to the quiescent cysteine electrophile 4-chloro-pyridine.(170) Using HBX 19818, it has been reported that disrupting USP7 reduces proliferation of human colon cancer cells, induces apoptosis, and disrupts the cell cycle.(169) A thiophene containing compound P22077 (56), which inhibits both USP7 and USP47, has been shown to inhibit neuroblastoma growth.(171) Further modification led to the development of P50429 (57).(172) Interestingly, a study indicated that both P22077 and P50429 covalently and irreversibly modify the cysteine residue at the active site of USP7 but via distinct chemical reactions.(173) Both reactions undergo the nucleophilic aromatic substitution; however, MS experiments revealed that different substructures are transferred to DUB cysteine from each inhibitor (Figure 9C). The authors speculated that the preferred attack on the pyridine in P50429 could be due to the reduced electrophilicity of the thiophene compared to the thiophene in P22077 or potentially more optimal trajectory for attack on the pyridine in the bound state. Using Ub-rhodamine assay, an USP7 inhibitor FT827 (58) was identified along with a noncovalent inhibitor FT671.(174) FT827 covalently modifies the cysteine residue through a vinylsulfonamide moiety and exclusively inhibits USP7 among a panel of 38 DUBs from diverse families. Cocrystal structure indicated that FT827 binds to the inactive apo state of USP7. Elaboration of a noncovalent inhibitor XL188 by incorporating a tetrahydroacridine warhead yielded a highly potent and selective irreversible USP7 inhibitor XL177A (60). It has been demonstrated that selective USP7 inhibition by XL177A results in cytotoxicity toward cancer cells mainly through a p53-dependent mechanism, and the sensitivity to USP7 inhibition is highly correlated with mutational status of the tumor suppressor p53.(175)
    The best-described USP9X inhibitor is WP1130 (previously known as Degrasyn, 55), which was originally identified in a screen for JAK2 inhibitors, but later found to inhibit DUB USP9X as well as USP5, USP14, and UCHL5.(176) The 2-cyano-3-acrylamide warhead can reversibly modify the cysteine. WP1130-mediated inhibition of DUBs led to downregulation of antiapoptotic Mcl-1 and upregulation of proapoptotic p53.(176) A derivative EOAI3402143 displayed improved aqueous solubility and greater inhibitory activity against USP9X and USP24. Intraperitoneal administration of the compound to MM1.S tumor-bearing mice significantly suppressed tumor growth, suggesting small molecule USP9X/USP24 inhibitors may have the therapeutic potential for treating myeloma.(177)

    Granzyme

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Granule-associated serine proteases known as granzymes (Gzms) are central to the function of CTL and NK cells and implicated in the pathogenesis of a broad range of human diseases. The pore-forming protein, perforin facilitates entry of granzymes into the cytoplasm of a target cell, where they access their substrates to carry out a series of proteolytic events, which result in cell death and elimination of infected and tumor cells.(178,179) Granzymes also regulate immune and inflammatory responses by controlling the survival of activated lymphocytes and mediating cleavage of extracellular substrates. There are five human granzyme genes: GzmA/B/H/K/M. Different granzymes have been found in a variety of cells of hematopoietic and nonhematopoietic origins with GzmA and GzmB being the predominant constituents of granules. Granzymes can be classified according to their cleavage specificity. GzmA and GzmK have trypsin-like activity, cleaving their substrates after basic residues such as arginine and lysine. Similar to caspases, GzmB cleaves the substrates after acidic residues, aspartic acid or glutamic acid. GzmH has chymotrypsin-like activity, cleaving after tyrosine or phenylalanine, and GzmM cleaves after leucine or methionine. Gzms A, B, K, and H are expressed in higher quantities in CTLs compared with NK cells, whereas GzmM is more abundant in NK cells. Macrophages, mast cells, and DCs also express granzymes but not perforin, suggesting perforin-independent, extracellular roles of granzymes. An increasing number of studies have suggested the potential importance of GzmB expressed in tumor cells.(180,181) Granzymes are stored within the granules as an inactive form to prevent host cell suicide. Endogenous inhibitors such as serpins also inhibit granzyme activity.(182) SerpinB9 protects cells from misdirected GzmB activity. SerpinC1 prevents GzmA activity in plasma.
    Major intracellular functions of granzymes are cytotoxicity and cytokine signaling. Cytotoxicity is potently induced by GzmB, which cleaves the pro-apoptotic molecule Bid to activate the mitochondrial pathway of apoptosis as well as directly activates caspases. The proteolytic activity of granzymes is also involved in gasdermin-mediated pyroptosis. Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell-released GzmB has been shown to activate caspase-3 in target cells, which then cleaves gasdermin E (GSDME), leading to target cell pyroptosis.(183) Recently, it has been demonstrated that GzmA from CTLs cleaves and activates gasdermin B (GSDMB) to induce target cell pyroptosis.(184) The granzyme pathway is an important component of tumor surveillance and clearance. However, granzyme can potentially cause graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) and graft rejection in allogenic bone marrow transplantation by killing normal cells, mediated by CD8+ CTL.(185) Extracellular functions, independent of perforin, have been reported for GzmA and GzmB and involve cleavage of extracellular matrix (ECM) and cell surface receptors, possibly to facilitate cytotoxic lymphocyte migration and immune cell filtration.(186,187) GzmA as a proinflammatory protease carries out cytokine signaling, which results in maturation and release of immunomodulating cytokines. In a recent study by Santiago et al., extracellular GzmA was found to contribute to gut inflammation and colorectal cancer development by inducing NF-κB-dependent IL-6 production in macrophages, which in turn leads to STAT3 activation.(188) The roles of GzmK and M remain unclear.
    Developing effective chemical tools for granzymes has largely been focused on GzmA and GzmB. In earlier studies, Krähenbühl et al. identified GPR-AMC to be the best substrate for GzmA among 12 peptide analogues tested.(189) The substrates with P1 Arg are most effectively cleaved by GzmA, whereas GzmB prefers Asp, Asn, Met, Ser, or Thr at the P1 position.(190) A few templates appeared to have potent inhibitory activity toward GzmA. FUT-175 (61, Figure 10) and its structurally related analogues display comparable inhibition, and the general serine protease inhibitor dichloroisocoumarin (DCI, 62) inhibits GzmA weakly.(191) Ph-HNCONCH-CiTEtOIC (63) showed Kobs/[I] value of 94 000 M–1 s–1 for human recombinant GzmA.(192) Several other unique structures such as guanidinobenzoates (p-Gua-C6H4-COOC6H4-CN) have been reported with potent GzmA inhibitory potential. However, their selectivity profiles have not been fully reported. A more systematic approach in identifying selective GzmA inhibitor was pursued with diphenyl phosphonate derivatives. Inspired by the potent inhibitory activities of ornithine, lysine, and amidino-based residues equipped with diphenyl phosphonate esters toward serine proteases, Powers and coworkers explored the templates for GzmA. In their initial screening, Z-(4-AmPhe)P(OPh)2 was found to have >116-fold selectivity toward GzmA over other serine proteases such as GzmK, tryptase, and trypsin.(193) Later, PS-SCL disclosed Ile-Gly-Asn (IGN) as the optimal recognition sequence for GzmA.(194) Combined with the previously discovered Am(PhGly)P(OPh)2 P1-warhead, a chemical probe bio-x-IGN(AmPhGly)P(OPh)2 (64) exhibited highly specific activity toward GzmA. In addition to natural basic amino acids reported, Kasperkiewicz and coworkers described that GzmA also recognizes unnatural residues at the P1 position such as phenylalanine with a guanidine group. A cell permeable ABP, SK15.5 (65) containing Tic-Gly-Oic-Arg recognition motif was able to distinguish GzmA from other granzymes and successfully used to detect GzmA in NK92 cells.(195)
