    A tripeptide AAD was initially identified as an effective recognition sequence for GzmB, which led to the discovery of irreversible inhibitor Z-AAD-CMK (66), although its inhibition rate is rather slow.(190) Later, PS-SCL revealed IEPD as the optimal sequence.(24) Truncation of the sequence proved to be ineffective, evidenced by a decrease in potency from Ac-IEPD-pNA to Ac-EPD-pNA. While these sequences were known to be important, a drastic influence was observed by different serine traps. GzmB clearly differentiated the substrates with the AMC fluorophore or p-nitroanilide showing the preference for IEPD sequence over IKPD. Surprisingly, the IEPD and IKPD substrates with a thiobenzyl ester were kinetically indistinguishable. Using a diphenyl phosphonate warhead, a chemical probe bio-x-IEPDP(OPh)2 showed specific inhibition of GzmB.(194) From the HyCoSuL screening, Nva-Ile-Glu-Oic-Asp was identified as a selective and potent leading sequence for GzmB.(196) TJ55i (68) showed improved kinetic parameters and was able to detect active GzmB in lysates from different NK cell lines. Recently, activity-based imaging probes for GzmB have been employed for monitoring the treatment efficacy of cancer immunotherapy with PET.(197,198) The study reported higher radionuclide signal intensity with 68Ga-NOTA-GZP (69) in tumor when treated with a combination of anti-CTLA-4 and anti-PD-1 antibodies compared to monotherapy or untreated mice, which suggest that the probe can be utilized to differentiate nonresponders from responders for immune checkpoint therapy.(198)
    VTI-1002 (structure unavailable) is the only commercially available covalent reversible GzmB inhibitor that is highly selective and potent. It inhibits GzmB-mediated cleavage of two key ECM proteins, decorin and fibronectin. Topical application of VTI-1002 gel has been shown to promote wound closure and tissue remodeling in diabetic burn wounds.(199) In the models of pemphigoid diseases, which are severe autoimmune skin blistering diseases induced by infiltration of autoantibody and immune cells at the dermal–epidermal junction, GzmB knockout or topical application of VTI-1002 significantly reduced total blistering area and severity, mediated by the inhibition of neutrophil accumulation and hemidesmosomal protein cleavage.(200)

    Neutrophil Elastase

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Neutrophils are one of the effector immune cells to arrive at the site of infection, representing the first line innate immune defense. Neutrophils contain four serine proteases (NSPs)—cathepsin G (CatG), neutrophil elastase (NE), proteinase 3 (PR3), and the recently discovered neutrophil proteinase 4 (NSP4)—that play important roles in the nonoxidative destruction of internalized pathogens, modulation of inflammatory processes, and controlling of cell signaling through cytokine/chemokine processing and activation of cell receptors. Deregulated NSPs have been implicated in the development of numerous inflammatory disorders.
    Human neutrophil elastase (HNE) belongs to a serine protease of chymotrypsin family. Displaying a broad substrate specificity, HNE degrades not only elastin but also a variety of ECM and plasma proteins, including collagen (types I–IV), fibronectin, laminin, and proteoglycans and pathogens. Owing to the shallow S1 pocket, HNE prefers substrates with small aliphatic P1 residues (Ala, Ile, or Val). Despite its name, neutrophil elastase is produced not only by neutrophils but also by immune cells such as macrophages and lymphocytes(201) and implicated in the control of immune responses and signal transduction. For example, HNE activates TLR4 to induce IL-8 expression and modulates cytokine signaling at the inflammation sites.(77) Neutrophil elastase is known to enhance IL-12p40 production by macrophages after stimulation with lipopolysaccharide (LPS) via transactivation of the PAR2/EGFR/TLR4 signaling pathway.(202) Through PAR1 signaling, NE induces apoptosis of lung endothelial cells and regulates their barrier integrity.(203) Neutrophil elastase has been shown to stimulate mucus hypersecretion from the airways of patients with chronic bronchitis and induce keratinocyte proliferation in psoriasis. Endogenous protein inhibitors that control the proteolytic activity of HNE are highly present in the respiratory tract and circulatory system.(204) Dysregulated activity of HNE contributes to the development of several inflammatory disorders such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchiectasis, respiratory distress syndrome, acute lung injury, cystic fibrosis, and rheumatoid arthritis. As NE is shown to enhance inflammation and disrupt matrix barrier integrity, it has been hypothesized that NE will likely facilitate cancer development. Indeed, neutrophil elastase expression and activity has been found to be upregulated in numerous cancer types.(205) In lung cancer patients, elevated serological neutrophil elastase is positively correlated with disease state and progression.(206)
    Almost every large pharmaceutical company has had an elastase inhibitor program, resulting in a myriad of HNE inhibitors with different pharmacophores. MeO-Suc-AAPV-CMK (70, Figure 11A) is an effective HNE inhibitor and has been particularly useful for structural studies.(207) Upon interaction with Ser195 in the active site, pyrrolidine tran-lactams and -lactones lead to ring opening that results in the formation of irreversible complex with the protein. SAR studies identified GW311616 (71) as one of the most potent inhibitors of HNE.(208) ONO-5046 (also known as sivelestat, 72) is one of the representative reversible inhibitors of neutrophil elastase.(209) ONO-5046 is found to undergo reversible acyl-deacylation mechanism, determined by LC-MS spectroscopy with four human sputum elastase isozymes.(210) Sivelestat has been approved for the treatment of acute respiratory failure in Japan; however, efforts to expand the country or indication scope have not been successful.
    Sieńczyk and coworkers have utilized Ugi and Passerini multicomponent reactions to rapidly construct a phosphonic peptidomimetic library with variations on the diphenyl phosphonate (DPP) warhead.(211) Among the synthesized pseudopeptides, Cbz-Met-O-Met-ValP(OC6H4-p-Cl)2 (73) showed potent HNE inhibition with no inhibitory activities toward chymotrypsin and trypsin. Using the DPP moiety with the P1 valine, a fluorescent ABP, Cy5-V-DPP was synthesized and tested to monitor the NE activation during colitis.(212) Cy5-V-DPP efficiently labeled recombinant NE and highly expressed NE in cells. However, it was unable to detect NE activity in colitis tissues, presumably due to insufficient sensitivity. The Drag laboratory identified Nle(O-Bzl)-Met(O)2-Oic-Abu as an optimal sequence for HNE. With high selectivity for HNE, ABPs PK101 (biotin tagged, 74) and PK105 (Cy5 tagged)(213,214) were used to define the presence of active elastase during the formation of neutrophil extracellular traps, which are the clusters of biologically active compounds, such as DNA and antipathogenic factors, that extrude into the extracellular space to trap and eliminate pathogens.(215) Crystal structure of the HNE-PK101 complex revealed key interactions important for HNE recognition (Figure 11B).(216) In particular, the interaction of the P3Met(O)2 residue within the S3 subsite showed how HNE can recognize post-translationally oxidized methionine residues in the oxidative environment of neutrophils during infection.(217) Also, an exopocket adjacent to the S4 subsite is shown to interact with the unnatural amino acid Nle(O-Bzl) in the P4 position. When used in mucosal biopsies from the inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) patients, the Cy5-tagged PK105 probe detected activated NE.(218) Followed by the success of using HyCoSuL method to identify selective recognition sequences for HNE, the same group developed a set of highly selective NSP small-molecule chemical tools that allow simultaneous detection of each serine protease in neutrophils. While CatG prefers large hydrophobic residues (Tyr or Phe) and NSP4 prefers Arg, both NE and PR3 prefer small hydrophobic residues such as Val or Ala. The comprehensive HyCoSuL screening led to the identification of optimal sequences of all four NSPs in addition to Nle(O-Bzl)-Met(O)2-Oic-Abu for NE: Glu(O-Bzl)-Lys(Ac)-hPro(Bzl)-Nva for PR3, His(Bzl)-Val-Pro-Phe for CatG, and hCha-Phe(guan)-Oic-Arg for NSP4.(214,219) Selected sequences were converted into diphenyl phosphonate activity-based probes tagged with N-terminal biotin or one of four fluorophores (BODIPYFL, Cy3, Cy5, or Cy7). When applied to freshly prepared unstimulated and PMA-stimulated neutrophils, the NSP fluorescent imaging probes revealed that individual serine proteases are localized unevenly in distinctive neutrophil azurophil granules, suggesting unknown mechanism of granule packing system.
    Alkyl and aryl sulfonyl fluorides have been known to covalently inhibit a number of serine proteases.(220,221) Sulfur fluoride exchange (SuFEx) chemistry, recently developed by the Sharpless group, representing a new generation of click chemistry, has facilitated rapid assembly of diverse serine protease inhibitors.(222) A covalent inhibitor, 2-(fluorosulfonyl)phenyl fluorosulfate (75) identified by SuFEx-enabled, agonistic approach showed IC50 of 0.24 μM for HNE and >833-fold selectivity over CatG.(223) 3-Oxo-β-sultam, which features an endocyclic acyl moiety next to the β-sultam nitrogen atom, has been reported to irreversibly inactivate serine hydrolases in vitro.(224,225) Nucleophilic attack on the 3-oxo-β-sultams could involve either acylation or sulfonylation. Cocrystal structure of HNE bound to the selected 3-oxo-β-sultam 8 (76) revealed that the mechanism of HNE inhibition by this chemotype is through sulfonylation of the catalytic serine residue.(226) Using ABPP-MudPIT (multidimensional protein identification technology), a biotinylated 3-oxo-β-sultam probe enriched several serine proteases including dipeptidyl peptidase (DPP) family members DPP7/9, prolyl endopeptidases (PREP), and fibroblast activating protein (FAP) in addition to HNE. The 3-oxo-β-sultam moiety appeared also to react with the conserved catalytic threonine in the proteasome subunits. Recently, the Gois group reported that diazaborine compound 77, in which the boron center is stabilized in the form of an aromatic B–N heterocycle, reversibly and selectively inhibits human neutrophil elastase with IC50 value of 2.7 μM, providing a new type of boron-containing warhead for serine proteases.(227) Similar to boronic acids, the boron center of diazaboines reacts with the catalytic serine residue and forms a reversible covalent bond.

    Dipeptidyl Peptidase 4

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The dipeptidyl peptidase (DPP) family has been implicated in various physiological and pathological processes of the immune system. Among them, dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), also known as T cell surface marker cluster of differentiation 26 (CD26), is a highly conserved membrane glycoprotein and serine protease that cleaves off an N-terminal dipeptide from protein substrates with Pro or Ala (or to a lesser extent Ser) in the last position prior to the scissile amide bond.(228,229) DPP4 is expressed ubiquitously in many tissues, including kidney, intestine, liver, lung, and also on immune cells (e.g., T cells, activated B and NK cells, and myeloid cells). DPP4 has been shown to cleave many gastrointestinal hormones, growth factors, and neuropeptides that share either the X-Pro or X-Ala motif at their N-terminus. DPP4 degrades insulinotrophic incretin hormones such as glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) and gastric inhibitory protein (GIP) and plays a major role in glucose homeostasis.(230,231) Thus, DPP4 has been a validated therapeutic target for the treatment of type 2 diabetes. DPP4 modulates immune responses by mediating cleavage of many cytokines and chemokines.(232,233) For example, stromal-derived factor 1 (SDF-1, also known as CXCL12) is rapidly degraded by circulating DPP4 in the peripheral blood. When treated with an orally active inhibitor of DPP4 in vivo, biologically active, full-length CXCL10 was preserved, which led to enhanced recruitment of lymphocytes into the tumor parenchyma.(234) DPP4 inhibition was found to augment the efficacy of tumor immunity. A large number of studies demonstrated that CD26/DPP4 plays an integral role in T cell activation. Recent in vitro findings indicated that CD26/DPP4 is able to trigger T cell activation and proliferation directly via CARMA1-mediated NF-κB activation.(235) CD26/DPP4 has been also described as a mediator of lymphocyte migration through the thymus. DPP4 has been linked to a number of diseases including autoimmune diabetes, asthma, multiple sclerosis, arthritis, and inflammatory bowel disease. In nonobese diabetic mice, DPP-4 inhibition was found to deregulate Th1 immune response, increase secretion of Th2 anti-inflammatory cytokines, activate Tregs, and prevent IL-17 production.(236)
    Several DPP-4 inhibitors (gliptins) have been successfully approved and used for 2 diabetes with good efficacy and safety profiles. Among the marketed DPP-4 inhibitors, vildagliptin (78, Figure 12)(237) and saxagliptin (79),(238) discovered by building on the substrate-derived Gly-Pro dipeptide scaffold, represent the peptidomimetic reversible covalent inhibitors. The cyanopyrrolidine moieties bind to the S1 subsite, forming a covalent bond between the nitrile group and Ser630, and the hydroxy adamantyl groups bind to the S2 subsite. While they bind in a similar mode, saxagliptin has activity fivefold higher than that of vildagliptin, which is attributed to the cyclopropanated cyanopyrrolidine of saxagliptin. Introduction of the cyclopropane moiety to enhance chemical stability of the cyanopyrrolidine afforded an additional hydrophobic interaction in the S1 pocket.(239) Saxagliptin has been shown to be effective and generally well tolerated and improve β-cell function in latent autoimmune diabetes in adults, a form of autoimmune diabetes caused primarily by autoimmune destruction of β-cells that has a later onset and slower progression toward absolute insulin dependency than type 1 diabetes.(240)
    Many of the DPP4 inhibitors used in earlier studies have been found to be nonspecific, inhibiting more than one DPP family member such as DPP2, DPP8, DPP9, FAP, and/or prolyl PREP because of their structural homology and similarities in substrate specificity. Dipeptide boronic acids Xaa-boroPro or Xaa-boroAla are potent DPP4 inhibitors, having Ki values in the picomolar range.(241) Val-boroPro (also called PT-100 and talabostat, 80), which inhibits DPP4 as well as DPP7, DPP8/9, and FAP,(242,243) has been in phase 3 clinical trials for cancer.(244,245) The ability of Val-boroPro to induce substantial tumor regressions in syngeneic mouse tumor models has been demonstrated to be immune mediated because the efficacy of Val-boroPro was found to be attenuated in lymphocyte-deficient mice.(246) It stimulates transcriptional upregulation of several immunomodulatory cytokines, including IL-1β, IL-6, G-CSF, and CXCL1, in both tumors and tumor-draining lymph nodes and increases serum levels of several cytokines, including G-CSF and CXCL1.(247) However, CD26/DPP4 appeared not to be involved in the antitumor activity of Val-boroPro since the antitumor activity was unchanged in CD26–/– mice. Recently, the Bachovchin group discovered that inhibition of DPP8 and DPP9 by Val-boroPro activates the inflammasome sensor protein NLRP1b in murine macrophages, which in turn activates procaspase-1 to mediate pyroptosis, suggesting that DPP8/9 serve as a checkpoint to restrain NLRP1b and the innate immune system.(248,249) Furthermore, it has been shown that Val-boroPro is cytotoxic to human acute myeloid leukemia (AML) cells. The CARD-containing protein CARD8, an NLRP1 homologue, has been shown to mediate DPP8/9 inhibitor-induced procaspase-1-dependent pyroptosis in human myeloid cells.(250)

    Immunoproteasome

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In most cells, the constitutive proteasome (CP), which is part of the ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS), is responsible for degradation of damaged or misfolded intracellular proteins tagged with ubiquitin and plays a critical role in maintaining protein homeostasis and regulating a variety of cellular processes. The proteasome is a barrel-shaped protein complex composed of a 20S core made up of four heptameric rings consisting of α and β subunits with 19S caps on either end of the core. The 19S regulatory subunit recognizes the ubiquitinylated proteins and shuttles them into the 20S core, where they are degraded into smaller peptides. The proteolytic activity of the proteasome is mediated by the β1, β2, and β5 catalytic subunits. Immune cells express an isoform of proteasome containing three distinct catalytic subunits, LMP2 (low-molecular mass polypeptide-2, β1i), MECL-1 (multicatalytic endopeptidase complex-like 1, β2i), and LMP7 (β5i). The immunoproteasome (IP) is also expressed in most nonimmune cells in response to a viral infection or after exposure to immunomodulatory cytokines such as IFN-γ and TNF-α.(251−253) The immunoproteasome plays an important role in antigen processing and presentation, cytokine production, and T cell differentiation. The immunoproteasome is assembled faster than the constitutive proteasomes and has a shorter lifespan, which indicates that the production and degradation of the immunoproteasome facilitate a dynamic turnover, allowing the rapid response to immune stressors and subsequent return to baseline levels after decline of the inflammatory challenge.(254) The catalytic subunits of the immunoproteasome exhibit differential cleavage preferences and efficiencies to help diversify the antigenic peptide repertoire.(255,256) Unlike standard β1 with caspase-like activity, the β1i has chymotrypsin-like activity that is capable of cleaving after hydrophobic amino acids. As a result, the immunoproteasome can produce more antigenic peptides with hydrophobic C-termini that can be processed to fit in the groove of MHC class I molecules to activate CD8+ T lymphocytes. The immunoproteasome can also degrade misfolded or damaged proteins formed as a result of oxidative stress or cytokine-stimulated protein synthesis.(257,258)
    Given the role of inflammatory cytokines in the formation of the immunoproteasome, the functions of the immunoproteasome have been extensively investigated in the context of inflammatory and autoimmune diseases. Elevated levels of immunoproteasome have been associated with a number of diseases, including ulcerative colitis, Crohn’s disease, IBD, and hepatitis. Immunoproteasome upregulation has been linked to changes in the proteasomal activity observed in a mouse model of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) and in clinical samples of multiple sclerosis patients.(259) The detection of immunoproteasomes in certain cancers and neurodegenerative diseases suggests its involvement in modulating the disease states. Encouraged by the success of FDA-approved proteasome inhibitors (bortezomib and carfilzomib), developing immunoproteasome-specific inhibitors has received growing interest from researchers. The Overkleeft group developed a cocktail of activity-based probes (81, 82, and 83) that allows for simultaneous detection of all six catalytic human proteasome subunits (Figure 13A).(260) In addition to its utility in assessing active-site specificity of proteasome inhibitors, the probes further demonstrated that many hematologic malignancies predominantly express immunoproteasomes.
    Crystal structures of murine proteasomes revealed key structural differences between the catalytic subunits of CP and IP and provided significant insights that help design specific inhibitors of immunoproteasome.(261,262) For example, bulky hydrophobic residues (Tyr, Trp, Phe) are well fit into the larger β5i S1 pocket whereas the S1 pocket of β5c only accommodates small amino acids (Ala or Val). The substitutions such as T20 V, T31F, R45L and T52A in the β1i S1 pocket were found to increase the hydrophobicity but reduce its dimension preferentially accommodating small hydrophobic residues. The substitutions T22A and A27 V in the β1i S3 subsite resulted also in a smaller pocket.
    Epoxyketone is the most commonly used warhead in proteasome inhibitors because of its high selectivity toward the N-terminal threonine residue. ONX-0914 (also called PR-957, 89, Figure 13B), the first epoxyketone-based peptidyl immunoproteasome-selective inhibitor reported, showed 20-fold selectivity for the β5i over β5.(263) ONX-0914 inhibited the production of IL-23, TNF-α, and IL-6 and offered significant therapeutic benefits in a mouse model of rheumatoid arthritis, reducing circulating autoantibodies. However, ONX-0914 suffers from poor solubility. The P1 substitution with a cyclopentene ring and the addition of a hydroxyl group to the β position of the P2 methyltyrosine increased solubility while maintaining selectivity for β5i. KZR-616 (90) exhibited overall improved activities toward all subunits of the immunoproteasome.(264) Studies have shown that simultaneous inhibition of at least two catalytic subunits of immunoproteasome (β5i/β2i or β5i/β1i) is required for the inhibition of cytokine expression. With a good profile of in vivo potency, KZR-616 is currently in phase 1b/2 clinical trials as the first immunoproteasome inhibitor for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).(265) With the dipeptide epoxyketone scaffold, selectivity for the β1i was achieved by introducing the motif that binds well within the S3 pocket. A selective β1i inhibitor KZR-504 (85) showed significantly improved in vivo stability.(266)
    UK-101 (84) was originated from the natural products epoxomicin and eponemycin.(267) Compared with epoxomicin, eponemycin preferentially inactivates the immuno-subunits over the constitutive proteasome. While keeping the N-terminal hydrophobic tail and C-terminal hydroxyl group of eponemycin, alanine was identified most promising in the P2 position.(268) UK-101 that contains a hydrophobic heptanoic tail at the N-terminus and a tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBDMS) ether group at the C-terminus covalently modifies and inhibits the β1i. UK-101 induced cell death in prostate cancer cells and suppressed in vivo tumor growth in a mouse xenograft model of human prostate cancer.(269) A peptide aldehyde inhibitor, IPSI-001 (Z-L-Nle-CHO, 86), was found to have >100-fold selectivity for the β1i over the β1. When used in multiple myeloma cells resistant to bortezomib, IPSI-001 resulted in accumulation of proapoptotic proteins and led to caspase-mediated apoptosis.(270) ML604440 (87), a boronate dipeptide, is a potent and specific inhibitor of the β1i.(271)
    A sulfonyl fluoride warhead was introduced to the peptide sequences identified optimal for the inhibition of immunoproteasome subunits.(272) The sulfonyl fluoride induces irreversible deactivation of the proteasome through polarity inversion and intramolecular cross-linking between Thr1 and Lys33, providing a novel mechanism of proteasome inhibition.(273) The PSF compound 3 (91), which features the extended peptide backbone of ONX-0914 by adding a homophenylalanine residue at the P4 site, showed improved selectivity for the β5i subunit.
    Recently, structure-guided virtual screening discovered nonpeptidic and reversible inhibitors of immunoproteasomes.(274,275) To further refine the potency, various electrophilic warheads were introduced to the initially identified reversible binders. Among them, the oxathiazolone warhead-bearing compound (93) offered selective Thr1 modification of the β5i.

    Perspectives and Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Chemical developments have long been instrumental in studying the immune system. Recent advances in chemical proteomics have further facilitated the annotation of function to poorly characterized proteins in immune cell signaling pathways and provided insights into creating molecules that could address immunological problems. Particularly, small molecules that modulate immune responses by altering protein activity through covalent modification represent an important class of agents. In this Review, we focused our discussion on the development of covalent ligands that target protease active site and highlighted their applications in activity-based protein profiling, imaging probe development, and inhibitor design. Being essential players in immunology, proteases are considered suitable immunomodulatory targets. By reviewing compounds reported, we have identified exciting opportunities for protease inhibitors as chemical immunomodulators and laid out general strategies that can guide the development of potent and selective probes.
    Proteases within the same subfamily share similar substrate and inhibitor specificities; thus, achieving target specificity has been the main challenge in developing small molecule protease inhibitors. Recent progress made in solid-phase peptide chemistry, combinatorial library synthesis, and chemical strategies incorporating unnatural amino acids, cyclic scaffolds, or nonpeptidic fragments into the recognition element has increased the structural diversity and enabled the design of selective protease inhibitors. To further diversify small molecule scaffolds, robust chemical methods that mitigate the number of synthetic steps as well as the need for chromatographic purification are highly desirable. For example, modular click chemistries such as azide–alkyne cycloaddition and SuFEx reaction rapidly generate a library of compounds that can be directly screened in vitro. Additionally, computational screening can quickly identify nonpeptic scaffolds and accelerate the drug design process when used appropriately. The development of covalent docking methods combining features of noncovalent binding interaction and covalent bond formation has demonstrated broad utility for screening large virtual libraries of electrophilic small molecules.(276) Docking protocols that can provide accurate and reliable predictions on how a molecular scaffold orients the electrophile in the active site will help make informed decisions while minimizing the number of compounds that need to be synthesized. Alternatively, approaches targeting the pro-forms of protease, locking the inactive conformation of the enzymes or exploring the primed side of substrates, might offer future opportunities to identify more potent and selective compounds.
    Once a recognition motif has been successfully optimized, careful consideration needs to be taken when choosing the electrophile because highly reactive electrophiles can negate the target specificity gained by the scaffold. Several recent studies have reported comprehensive examinations of intrinsic reactivity and promiscuity of various electrophiles,(277,278) which provide a basic guideline that can be applied to the covalent compound design. Covalent inhibitors using quiescent or latent electrophiles such as 4-halopyridine and terminal alkyne, or reversible electrophiles such as α-ketoamide, α-cyanoacrylamide, and boronic acid have attracted particular attention in the field of protease inhibition. The nature of the reactive warhead contributes not only to reactivity and selectivity but also to metabolic stability and tissue distribution of the covalent ligands. There is still a high demand for novel warheads. As proven successful in the past (e.g., cathepsin and proteasome inhibitors), looking for molecules from natural sources will help discover new chemical entities and inspire researchers to come up with new chemistry. Reactivity-guided isolation for electrophilic natural products utilizing the inherent reactivity of a metabolite complements traditional bioactivity-guided isolation and physicochemical property-guided fractionation and offers a promising approach for the development of screening libraries.(279) For metalloproteases and aspartyl proteases that use water as a nucleophile to hydrolyze peptide bonds, photochemical methods have been successfully used to form a covalent bond between the compound and the enzyme.
    Another major challenge in the development of protease inhibitors is obtaining a clear understanding of how proteases carry out their biological functions and validating them carefully as drug targets. This is extremely difficult because a single protease can have multiple functions, and multiple proteases can also work together to achieve the same goal. A further complication arises because of the high complexity of protease regulation. Activity-based probes have proven to be powerful chemical tools to assess and visualize the activity and localization of proteases in living cells, whole organisms, or in vivo. Use of a cocktail of probes that are differently labeled or a multivariate probe that requires the processing by multiple enzymes allows for parallel measurement of multiple protease activities in complex multifactorial diseases. Performing assays in a biological context, when coupled with effective tools, has the potential to provide more accurate information about potency, selectivity, efficacy, and toxicity of the inhibitor.
    As typically flagged as structural alerts, covalent ligands have been rarely screened in HTS. However, high-throughput phenotypic screenings of mild electrophile fragments in combination with chemical proteomic methods will mitigate concerns about the in vivo promiscuity and idiosyncratic toxicity of covalent compounds. Although it remains highly challenging, development of high-throughput phenotypic screening and multiplex assay that recapitulate the complex immune response network will accelerate the discovery of small molecule immunomodulators with favorable pharmacological properties. Overall, we believe that the advent of new chemical tools and proteomic approaches that enable global protein profiling will bring synergies to the development of protease inhibitors within the field of chemical immunology.

      Biological effects of cyclosporin A: a new antilymphocytic agent
      Borel, J. F.; Feurer, Camille; Gubler, H. U.; Staehelin, H.
      Agents and Actions (1976), 6 (4), 468-75CODEN: AGACBH; ISSN:0065-4299.
      Cyclosporin A [59865-13-3] suppressed both humoral and cellular immunity in lab. animals in a reproducible and dose-dependent manner. Cyclosporin A also exhibited antiphlogistic effects in a chronic, but not in acute inflammatory models. Its low myelotoxicity indicates that cyclosporin A should undergo clin. investigation as an immunosuppressant and antiinflammatory agent.

      Cyclosporin A, FK506 and rapamycin: more than just immunosuppression
      Kunz, Jeannette; Hall, Michael N.
      Trends in Biochemical Sciences (1993), 18 (9), 334-8CODEN: TBSCDB; ISSN:0968-0004.
      A review with 35 refs. The mechanisms of action of the immunosuppressive drugs cyclosphorin A(CsA), FK506 and rapamycin are strikingly conserved from yeast to human T cells. Recent results obtained with yeast corroborate calcineurin as the target of CsA-cyclophilin and FK506-FKBP complexes, and reveal a phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase homolog as the target of the rapamycin-FKBP complex.

      Trial Watch: Toll-like receptor agonists in cancer immunotherapy
      Smith, Melody; Garcia-Martinez, Elena; Pitter, Michael R.; Fucikova, Jitka; Spisek, Radek; Zitvogel, Laurence; Kroemer, Guido; Galluzzi, Lorenzo

      Toll-like receptor (TLR) agonists demonstrate therapeutic promise as immunol. adjuvants for anticancer immunotherapy. To date, three TLR agonists have been approved by US regulatory agencies for use in cancer patients. Addnl., the potential of hitherto exptl. TLR ligands to mediate clin. useful immunostimulatory effects has been extensively investigated over the past few years. Here, we summarize recent preclin. and clin. advances in the development of TLR agonists for cancer therapy.

      5
      Immune modulation in cancer with antibodies
      Page, David B.; Postow, Michael A.; Callahan, Margaret K.; Allison, James P.; Wolchok, Jedd D.
      Annual Review of Medicine (2014), 65 (), 185-202CODEN: ARMCAH; ISSN:0066-4219. (Annual Reviews)
      A review. Ipilimumab is the prototypical immunomodulatory antibody, approved by the FDA in 2011 for advanced melanoma on the basis of survival benefit. Since that time, we have made significant strides in optimizing this therapy: we have characterized the spectrum of immune-related adverse events and learned how to mitigate them with treatment algorithms, discovered potential biomarkers of activity, and identified the potential synergy between checkpoint modulation and other therapeutic modalities. Recent phase I trials have established the efficacy and safety of next-generation checkpoint agents, including PD-1 and PD-L1 inhibitors, across multiple tumor types. Much work lies ahead in developing these next-generation checkpoint agents, testing them in combination, and detg. how to integrate them into the treatment paradigms of various tumor types.

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Current state of anti-PD-L1 and anti-PD-1 agents in cancer therapy
      Swaika, Abhisek; Hammond, William A.; Joseph, Richard W.
      Molecular Immunology (2015), 67 (2_Part_A), 4-17CODEN: MOIMD5; ISSN:0161-5890. (Elsevier)
      A review. Immunotherapy for the treatment of cancer is rapidly evolving from therapies that globally and non-specifically simulate the immune system to more targeted activation of individual components of the immune system. The net result of this targeted approach is decreased toxicity and increased efficacy of immunotherapy. More specifically, therapies that inhibit the interaction between programmed death ligand 1 (PD-L1), present on the surface of tumor or antigen-presenting cells, and programmed death 1 (PD-1), present on the surface of activated lymphocytes, are generating much excitement and enthusiasm, even in malignancies that are not traditionally considered to be immunogenic. Herein, we review the current landscape of anti-PD-1 and anti-PD-L1 therapies in the world of oncol. We have performed a comprehensive literature search on the data available through PubMed, Medline, Scopus, the ClinicalTrials.gov registry, and abstrs. from major oncol. meetings in order to summarize the clin. data of anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapies.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXjtVyrsLc%253D&md5=c897e8ecbf612233ad4e07da5979ecc8

      Kershaw, M. H.; Westwood, J. A.; Slaney, C. Y.; Darcy, P. K. Clinical application of genetically modified T cells in cancer therapy. Clin. Transl. Immunol. 2014, 3 (5), e16  DOI: 10.1038/cti.2014.7
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Clinical application of genetically modified T cells in cancer therapy
      Kershaw, Michael H.; Westwood, Jennifer A.; Slaney, Clare Y.; Darcy, Phillip K.
      Clinical and Translational Immunology (2014), 3 (), e16/1-e16/7, 7CODEN: CTILBR; ISSN:2050-0068. (NPG Nature Asia-Pacific)
      Immunotherapies are emerging as highly promising approaches for the treatment of cancer. In these approaches, a variety of materials are used to boost immunity against malignant cells. A key component of many of these approaches is functional tumor-specific T cells, but the existence and activity of sufficient T cells in the immune repertoire is not always the case. Recent methods of generating tumor-specific T cells include the genetic modification of patient lymphocytes with receptors to endow them with tumor specificity. These T cells are then expanded in vitro followed by infusion of the patient in adoptive cell transfer protocols. Genes used to modify T cells include those encoding T-cell receptors and chimeric antigen receptors. In this review, we provide an introduction to the field of genetic engineering of T cells followed by details of their use against cancer in the clinic.

      Hailfinger, S.; Rebeaud, F.; Thome, M. Adapter and enzymatic functions of proteases in T-cell activation. Immunol. Rev. 2009, 232 (1), 334– 347,  DOI: 10.1111/j.1600-065X.2009.00830.x
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Adapter and enzymatic functions of proteases in T-cell activation
      Hailfinger, Stephan; Rebeaud, Fabien; Thome, Margot
      Immunological Reviews (2009), 232 (1), 334-347CODEN: IMRED2; ISSN:1600-065X. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
      A review. Proteases control many vital aspects of humoral and cellular immune responses, including the maturation of cytokines and the killing of target cells. Recently, it has become evident that triggering of the T-cell receptor controls T-cell proliferation through proteases such as mucosa-assocd. lymphoid tissue 1 (MALT1) and Caspase-8 that act both as adapters and enzymes. Here, we discuss the role of these and other proteases that are relevant to the control of the T-cell response and represent interesting targets of therapeutic immunomodulation.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsFGlsLrN&md5=518caa776a1b00b5d270d2dbe42e93ca

      Cromm, P. M.; Crews, C. M. The proteasome in modern drug discovery: second life of a highly valuable drug target. ACS Cent. Sci. 2017, 3 (8), 830– 838,  DOI: 10.1021/acscentsci.7b00252
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      The Proteasome in Modern Drug Discovery: Second Life of a Highly Valuable Drug Target
      Cromm, Philipp M.; Crews, Craig M.
      ACS Central Science (2017), 3 (8), 830-838CODEN: ACSCII; ISSN:2374-7951. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. As the central figure of the cellular protein degrdn. machinery, the proteasome is crit. for cell survival. Having been extensively targeted for inhibition, the constitutive proteasome has proven its role as a highly valuable drug target. However, recent advances in the protein homeostasis field suggest that addnl. chapters can be added to this successful story. For example, selective immunoproteasome inhibition promises high clin. efficacy for autoimmune disorders and inflammation, and proteasome inhibitors might serve as novel therapeutics for malaria or other microorganisms. Furthermore, utilizing the destructive force of the proteasome for selective degrdn. of essential drivers of human disorders has opened up a new and exciting area of drug discovery. Thus, the field of proteasome drug discovery still holds exciting questions to be answered and does not simply end with inhibiting the constitutive proteasome.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXht1Orsb3M&md5=91f26fd1133db650c0b4b4f43a461354
    11. 11
      Li, H.; O’Donoghue, A. J.; van der Linden, W. A.; Xie, S. C.; Yoo, E.; Foe, I. T.; Tilley, L.; Craik, C. S.; da Fonseca, P. C. A.; Bogyo, M. Structure- and function-based design of Plasmodium-selective proteasome inhibitors. Nature 2016, 530 (7589), 233– 236,  DOI: 10.1038/nature16936
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Structure- and function-based design of Plasmodium-selective proteasome inhibitors
      Li, Hao; O'Donoghue, Anthony J.; van der Linden, Wouter A.; Xie, Stanley C.; Yoo, Euna; Foe, Ian T.; Tilley, Leann; Craik, Charles S.; da Fonseca, Paula C. A.; Bogyo, Matthew
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2016), 530 (7589), 233-236CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      The proteasome is a multi-component protease complex responsible for regulating key processes such as the cell cycle and antigen presentation. Compds. that target the proteasome are potentially valuable tools for the treatment of pathogens that depend on proteasome function for survival and replication. In particular, proteasome inhibitors have been shown to be toxic for the malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum at all stages of its life cycle. Most compds. that have been tested against the parasite also inhibit the mammalian proteasome, resulting in toxicity that precludes their use as therapeutic agents. Therefore, better definition of the substrate specificity and structural properties of the Plasmodium proteasome could enable the development of compds. with sufficient selectivity to allow their use as anti-malarial agents. To accomplish this goal, here the authors use a substrate profiling method to uncover differences in the specificities of the human and P. falciparum proteasome. The authors design inhibitors based on amino-acid preferences specific to the parasite proteasome, and find that they preferentially inhibit the β2-subunit. The authors det. the structure of the P. falciparum 20S proteasome bound to the inhibitor using cryo-electron microscopy and single-particle anal., to a resoln. of 3.6 Å. These data reveal the unusually open P. falciparum β2 active site and provide valuable information about active-site architecture that can be used to further refine inhibitor design. Furthermore, consistent with the recent finding that the proteasome is important for stress pathways assocd. with resistance of artemisinin family anti-malarials, the authors observe growth inhibition synergism with low doses of this β2-selective inhibitor in artemisinin-sensitive and -resistant parasites. Finally, the authors demonstrate that a parasite-selective inhibitor could be used to attenuate parasite growth in vivo without appreciable toxicity to the host. Thus, the Plasmodium proteasome is a chem. tractable target that could be exploited by next-generation anti-malarial agents.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XisVyrsr8%253D&md5=f24a562efb64dd533a7dbcfeff4171af
    12. 12
      Yoo, E.; Stokes, B. H.; de Jong, H.; Vanaerschot, M.; Kumar, T. R. S.; Lawrence, N.; Njoroge, M.; Garcia, A.; Van der Westhuyzen, R.; Momper, J. D.; Ng, C. L.; Fidock, D. A.; Bogyo, M. Defining the determinants of specificity of Plasmodium proteasome inhibitors. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2018, 140 (36), 11424– 11437,  DOI: 10.1021/jacs.8b06656
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Defining the Determinants of Specificity of Plasmodium Proteasome Inhibitors
      Yoo, Euna; Stokes, Barbara H.; de Jong, Hanna; Vanaerschot, Manu; Kumar, T. R. S.; Lawrence, Nina; Njoroge, Mathew; Garcia, Arnold; Van der Westhuyzen, Renier; Momper, Jeremiah D.; Ng, Caroline L.; Fidock, David A.; Bogyo, Matthew
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2018), 140 (36), 11424-11437CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The Plasmodium proteasome is an emerging antimalarial target due to its essential role in all the major life cycle stages of the parasite and its contribution to the establishment of resistance to artemisinin (ART)-based therapies. However, because of a similarly essential role for the host proteasome, the key property of any antiproteasome therapeutic is selectivity. Several parasite-specific proteasome inhibitors have recently been reported, however, their selectivity must be improved to enable clin. development. Here we describe screening of diverse libraries of non-natural synthetic fluorogenic substrates to identify determinants at multiple positions on the substrate that produce enhanced selectivity. We find that selection of an optimal electrophilic "warhead" is essential to enable high selectivity that is driven by the peptide binding elements on the inhibitor. We also find that host cell toxicity is dictated by the extent of coinhibition of the human β2 and β5 subunits. Using this information, we identify compds. with over 3 orders of magnitude selectivity for the parasite enzyme. Optimization of the pharmacol. properties resulted in mols. that retained high potency and selectivity, were sol., sufficiently metabolically stable and orally bioavailable. These mols. are highly synergistic with ART and can clear parasites in a mouse model of infection, making them promising leads as antimalarial drugs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhsV2lsLbN&md5=990e0b5097087ff76681f901b2c8f35f

      Cravatt, B. F.; Wright, A. T.; Kozarich, J. W. Activity-based protein profiling: from enzyme chemistry to proteomic chemistry. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 2008, 77 (1), 383– 414,  DOI: 10.1146/annurev.biochem.75.101304.124125
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13
      Activity-based protein profiling: From enzyme chemistry to proteomic chemistry
      Cravatt, Benjamin F.; Wright, Aaron T.; Kozarich, John W.
      Annual Review of Biochemistry (2008), 77 (), 383-414CODEN: ARBOAW; ISSN:0066-4154. (Annual Reviews Inc.)
      A review. Genome sequencing projects have provided researchers with a complete inventory of the predicted proteins produced by eukaryotic and prokaryotic organisms. Assignment of functions to these proteins represents one of the principal challenges for the field of proteomics. Activity-based protein profiling (ABPP) has emerged as a powerful chem. proteomic strategy to characterize enzyme function directly in native biol. systems on a global scale. Here, the authors review the basic technol. of ABPP, the enzyme classes addressable by this method, and the biol. discoveries attributable to its application.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXos1ekur0%253D&md5=2f2c471169d2473f7024eeb41d4eaecd

      Poreba, M.; Groborz, K. M.; Rut, W.; Pore, M.; Snipas, S. J.; Vizovisek, M.; Turk, B.; Kuhn, P.; Drag, M.; Salvesen, G. S. Multiplexed probing of proteolytic enzymes using mass cytometry-compatible activity-based probes. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2020, 142 (39), 16704– 16715,  DOI: 10.1021/jacs.0c06762

      14
      Multiplexed Probing of Proteolytic Enzymes Using Mass Cytometry-Compatible Activity-Based Probes
      Poreba, Marcin; Groborz, Katarzyna M.; Rut, Wioletta; Pore, Milind; Snipas, Scott J.; Vizovisek, Matej; Turk, Boris; Kuhn, Peter; Drag, Marcin; Salvesen, Guy S.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2020), 142 (39), 16704-16715CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The subset of the proteome that contains enzymes in their catalytically active form can be interrogated by using probes targeted toward individual specific enzymes. A subset of such enzymes are proteases that are frequently studied with activity-based probes, small inhibitors equipped with a detectable tag, commonly a fluorophore. Due to the spectral overlap of these commonly used fluorophores, multiplex anal. becomes limited. To overcome this, we developed a series of protease-selective lanthanide-labeled probes compatible with mass cytometry giving us the ability to monitor the activity of multiple proteases in parallel. Using these probes, we were able to identify the distribution of four proteases with different active site geometries in three cell lines and peripheral blood mononuclear cells. This provides a framework for the use of mass cytometry for multiplexed enzyme activity detection.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXhvValtbrP&md5=ab26ce581c552d3cf9ebdad09a45fa30
    15. 15
      Weerapana, E.; Wang, C.; Simon, G. M.; Richter, F.; Khare, S.; Dillon, M. B. D.; Bachovchin, D. A.; Mowen, K.; Baker, D.; Cravatt, B. F. Quantitative reactivity profiling predicts functional cysteines in proteomes. Nature 2010, 468 (7325), 790– 795,  DOI: 10.1038/nature09472
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      15
      Quantitative reactivity profiling predicts functional cysteines in proteomes
      Weerapana, Eranthie; Wang, Chu; Simon, Gabriel M.; Richter, Florian; Khare, Sagar; Dillon, Myles B. D.; Bachovchin, Daniel A.; Mowen, Kerri; Baker, David; Cravatt, Benjamin F.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2010), 468 (7325), 790-795CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Cysteine is the most intrinsically nucleophilic amino acid in proteins, where its reactivity is tuned to perform diverse biochem. functions. The absence of a consensus sequence that defines functional cysteines in proteins has hindered their discovery and characterization. Here we describe a proteomics method to profile quant. the intrinsic reactivity of cysteine residues en masse directly in native biol. systems. Hyper-reactivity was a rare feature among cysteines and it was found to specify a wide range of activities, including nucleophilic and reductive catalysis and sites of oxidative modification. Hyper-reactive cysteines were identified in several proteins of uncharacterized function, including a residue conserved across eukaryotic phylogeny that we show is required for yeast viability and is involved in iron-sulfur protein biogenesis. We also demonstrate that quant. reactivity profiling can form the basis for screening and functional assignment of cysteines in computationally designed proteins, where it discriminated catalytically active from inactive cysteine hydrolase designs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhsVGhsr%252FI&md5=277e436e7a8f4dfff0b548bce52ac40d
    16. 16
      Leung, D.; Hardouin, C.; Boger, D. L.; Cravatt, B. F. Discovering potent and selective reversible inhibitors of enzymes in complex proteomes. Nat. Biotechnol. 2003, 21 (6), 687– 691,  DOI: 10.1038/nbt826
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16
      Discovering potent and selective reversible inhibitors of enzymes in complex proteomes
      Leung, Donmienne; Hardouin, Christophe; Boger, Dale L.; Cravatt, Benjamin F.
      Nature Biotechnology (2003), 21 (6), 687-691CODEN: NABIF9; ISSN:1087-0156. (Nature Publishing Group)
      To realize the promise of genomics-based therapeutics, new methods are needed to accelerate the discovery of small mols. that selectively modulate protein activity. Toward this end, advances in combinatorial synthesis have provided unprecedented access to large compd. libraries of considerable structural complexity and diversity, shifting the bottleneck in drug discovery to the development of efficient screens for protein targets. Screening for reversible enzyme inhibitors typically requires extensive target-specific work, including protein expression and purifn., as well as the development of specific substrate assays. Here we report a proteomic method for the discovery of reversible enzyme inhibitors that avoids these steps. We show that competitive profiling of a library of candidate serine hydrolase inhibitors in complex proteomes with activity-based chem. probes identifies nanomolar reversible inhibitors of several enzymes simultaneously, including the endocannabinoid-degrading enzyme fatty acid amide hydrolase (FAAH), triacylglycerol hydrolase (TGH) and an uncharacterized membrane-assocd. hydrolase that lacks known substrates. The strategy tests inhibitors against numerous enzymes in parallel, assigning both potency and selectivity factors to each agent. In this way, promiscuous inhibitors were readily rejected in favor of equally potent compds. with 500-fold or greater selectivity for their targets.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXktFSlu7o%253D&md5=3e9946306058b4a832fb046f1e49a9f0
    17. 17
      Backus, K. M.; Correia, B. E.; Lum, K. M.; Forli, S.; Horning, B. D.; González-Páez, G. E.; Chatterjee, S.; Lanning, B. R.; Teijaro, J. R.; Olson, A. J.; Wolan, D. W.; Cravatt, B. F. Proteome-wide covalent ligand discovery in native biological systems. Nature 2016, 534 (7608), 570– 574,  DOI: 10.1038/nature18002
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17
      Proteome-wide covalent ligand discovery in native biological systems
      Backus, Keriann M.; Correia, Bruno E.; Lum, Kenneth M.; Forli, Stefano; Horning, Benjamin D.; Gonzalez-Paez, Gonzalo E.; Chatterjee, Sandip; Lanning, Bryan R.; Teijaro, John R.; Olson, Arthur J.; Wolan, Dennis W.; Cravatt, Benjamin F.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2016), 534 (7608), 570-574CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Small mols. are powerful tools for investigating protein function and can serve as leads for new therapeutics. Most human proteins, however, lack small-mol. ligands, and entire protein classes are considered 'undruggable'. Fragment-based ligand discovery can identify small-mol. probes for proteins that have proven difficult to target using high-throughput screening of complex compd. libraries. Although reversibly binding ligands are commonly pursued, covalent fragments provide an alternative route to small-mol. probes, including those that can access regions of proteins that are difficult to target through binding affinity alone. Here we report a quant. anal. of cysteine-reactive small-mol. fragments screened against thousands of proteins in human proteomes and cells. Covalent ligands were identified for >700 cysteines found in both druggable proteins and proteins deficient in chem. probes, including transcription factors, adaptor/scaffolding proteins, and uncharacterized proteins. Among the atypical ligand-protein interactions discovered were compds. that react preferentially with pro- (inactive) caspases. We used these ligands to distinguish extrinsic apoptosis pathways in human cell lines vs. primary human T cells, showing that the former is largely mediated by caspase-8 while the latter depends on both caspase-8 and -10. Fragment-based covalent ligand discovery provides a greatly expanded portrait of the ligandable proteome and furnishes compds. that can illuminate protein functions in native biol. systems.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtVSksbnN&md5=6fab087c042de735f8a5931e9f5b946c

      Vinogradova, E. V.; Zhang, X.; Remillard, D.; Lazar, D. C.; Suciu, R. M.; Wang, Y.; Bianco, G.; Yamashita, Y.; Crowley, V. M.; Schafroth, M. A.; Yokoyama, M.; Konrad, D. B.; Lum, K.       An Activity-Guided Map of Electrophile-Cysteine Interactions in Primary Human T Cells
      Vinogradova, Ekaterina V.; Zhang, Xiaoyu; Remillard, David; Lazar, Daniel C.; Suciu, Radu M.; Wang, Yujia; Bianco, Giulia; Yamashita, Yu; Crowley, Vincent M.; Schafroth, Michael A.; Yokoyama, Minoru; Konrad, David B.; Lum, Kenneth M.; Simon, Gabriel M.; Kemper, Esther K.; Lazear, Michael R.; Yin, Sifei; Blewett, Megan M.; Dix, Melissa M.; Nguyen, Nhan; Shokhirev, Maxim N.; Chin, Emily N.; Lairson, Luke L.; Melillo, Bruno; Schreiber, Stuart L.; Forli, Stefano; Teijaro, John R.; Cravatt, Benjamin F.
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2020), 182 (4), 1009-1026.e29CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      Electrophilic compds. originating from nature or chem. synthesis have profound effects on immune cells. These compds. are thought to act by cysteine modification to alter the functions of immune-relevant proteins; however, our understanding of electrophile-sensitive cysteines in the human immune proteome remains limited. Here, we present a global map of cysteines in primary human T cells that are susceptible to covalent modification by electrophilic small mols. More than 3,000 covalently liganded cysteines were found on functionally and structurally diverse proteins, including many that play fundamental roles in immunol. We further show that electrophilic compds. can impair T cell activation by distinct mechanisms involving the direct functional perturbation and/or degrdn. of proteins. Our findings reveal a rich content of ligandable cysteines in human T cells and point to electrophilic small mols. as a fertile source for chem. probes and ultimately therapeutics that modulate immunol. processes and their assocd. disorders.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXhsFShs7rJ&md5=9623b13c847b2088059b2157af63451f

      Tonge, P. J. Drug-target kinetics in drug discovery. ACS Chem. Neurosci. 2018, 9 (1), 29– 39,  DOI: 10.1021/acschemneuro.7b00185
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      19
      Drug-Target Kinetics in Drug Discovery
      Tonge, Peter J.
      ACS Chemical Neuroscience (2018), 9 (1), 29-39CODEN: ACNCDM; ISSN:1948-7193. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. The development of therapies for the treatment of neurol. cancer faces a no. of major challenges including the synthesis of small mol. agents that can penetrate the blood brain barrier (BBB). Given the likelihood that in many cases drug exposure will be lower in the CNS than in systemic circulation, it follows that strategies should be employed that can sustain target engagement at low drug concn. Time dependent target occupancy is a function of both the drug and target concn. as well as the thermodn. and kinetic parameters that describe the binding reaction coordinate, and sustained target occupancy can be achieved through structural modifications that increase target (re)binding and/or that decrease the rate of drug dissocn. The discovery and deployment of compds. with optimized kinetic effects requires information on the structure-kinetic relationships that modulate the kinetics of binding, and the mol. factors that control the translation of drug-target kinetics to time-dependent drug activity in the disease state. This review first introduces the potential benefits of drug-target kinetics, such as the ability to delineate both thermodn. and kinetic selectivity, and then describes factors, such as target vulnerability, that impact the utility of kinetic selectivity. The review concludes with a description of a mechanistic PK/PD model that integrates drug-target kinetics into predictions of drug activity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtVeku7%252FN&md5=59dde9100672e664d4b3b77a5f171b68

      Lebraud, H.; Surova, O.; Courtin, A.; O’Reilly, M.; Valenzano, C. R.; Nordlund, P.; Heightman, T. D. Quantitation of ERK1/2 inhibitor cellular target occupancies with a reversible slow off-rate probe. Chem. Sci. 2018, 9 (45), 8608– 8618,  DOI: 10.1039/C8SC02754D
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      20
      Quantitation of ERK1/2 inhibitor cellular target occupancies with a reversible slow off-rate probe
      Lebraud, Honorine; Surova, Olga; Courtin, Aurelie; O'Reilly, Marc; Valenzano, Chiara R.; Nordlund, Par; Heightman, Tom D.
      Chemical Science (2018), 9 (45), 8608-8618CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Target engagement is a key concept in drug discovery and its direct measurement can provide a quant. understanding of drug efficacy and/or toxicity. Failure to demonstrate target occupancy in relevant cells and tissues has been recognized as a contributing factor to the low success rate of clin. drug development. Several techniques are emerging to quantify target engagement in cells; however, in situ measurements remain challenging, mainly due to tech. limitations. Here, we report the development of a non-covalent clickable probe, based on SCH772984, a slow off-rate ERK1/2 inhibitor, which enabled efficient pull down of ERK1/2 protein via click reaction with tetrazine tagged agarose beads. This was used in a competition setting to measure relative target occupancy by selected ERK1/2 inhibitors. As a ref. we used the cellular thermal shift assay, a label-free biophys. assay relying solely on ligand-induced thermodn. stabilization of proteins. To validate the EC50 values measured by both methods, the results were compared with IC50 data for the phosphorylation of RSK, a downstream substrate of ERK1/2 used as a functional biomarker of ERK1/2 inhibition. We showed that a slow off-rate reversible probe can be used to efficiently pull down cellular proteins, significantly extending the potential of the approach beyond the need for covalent or photoaffinity warheads.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhslCnt7rP&md5=80d8668a3fc75e41bf4cb3ba1260d6ca

      O’Donoghue, A. J.; Eroy-Reveles, A. A.; Knudsen, G. M.; Ingram, J.; Zhou, M.; Statnekov, J. B.; Greninger, A. L.; Hostetter, D. R.; Qu, G.; Maltby, D. A.; Anderson, M. O.; DeRisi, J.       Global identification of peptidase specificity by multiplex substrate profiling
      O'Donoghue, Anthony J.; Eroy-Reveles, A. Alegra; Knudsen, Giselle M.; Ingram, Jessica; Zhou, Min; Statnekov, Jacob B.; Greninger, Alexander L.; Hostetter, Daniel R.; Qu, Gang; Maltby, David A.; Anderson, Marc O.; DeRisi, Joseph L.; McKerrow, James H.; Burlingame, Alma L.; Craik, Charles S.
      Nature Methods (2012), 9 (11), 1095-1100CODEN: NMAEA3; ISSN:1548-7091. (Nature Publishing Group)
      The authors developed a simple and rapid multiplex substrate-profiling method to reveal the substrate specificity of any endo- or exopeptidase using liq. chromatog.-tandem mass spectrometry sequencing. The authors generated a physicochem. diverse library of peptides by incorporating all combinations of neighbor and near-neighbor amino acid pairs into decapeptide sequences that are flanked by unique dipeptides at each terminus. Addn. of a panel of evolutionarily diverse peptidases to a mixt. of these tetradecapeptides generated information on prime and nonprime sites as well as on substrate specificity that matched or expanded upon known substrate motifs. This method biochem. confirmed the activity of the klassevirus 3C protein responsible for polypeptide processing and allowed granzyme B substrates to be ranked by enzymic turnover efficiency using label-free quantitation of precursor-ion abundance. Addnl., the proteolytic secretions from schistosome parasitic flatworm larvae and a pancreatic cancer cell line were deconvoluted in a subtractive strategy using class-specific peptidase inhibitors.

      Harris, J. L.; Backes, B. J.; Leonetti, F.; Mahrus, S.; Ellman, J. A.; Craik, C. S. Rapid and general profiling of protease specificity by using combinatorial fluorogenic substrate libraries. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000, 97 (14), 7754– 7759,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.140132697
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      22
      Rapid and general profiling of protease specificity by using combinatorial fluorogenic substrate libraries
      Harris, Jennifer L.; Backes, Bradley J.; Leonetti, Francesco; Mahrus, Sami; Ellman, Jonathan A.; Craik, Charles S.
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2000), 97 (14), 7754-7759CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
      A method is presented for the prepn. and use of fluorogenic peptide substrates that allows for the configuration of general substrate libraries to rapidly identify the primary and extended specificity of proteases. The substrates contain the fluorogenic leaving group 7-amino-4-carbamoylmethylcoumarin (ACC). Substrates incorporating the ACC leaving group show kinetic profiles comparable to those with the traditionally used 7-amino-4-methylcoumarin (AMC) leaving group. The bifunctional nature of ACC allows for the efficient prodn. of single substrates and substrate libraries by using 9-fluorenylmethoxycarbonyl (Fmoc)-based solid-phase synthesis techniques. The approx. 3-fold-increased quantum yield of ACC over AMC permits redn. in enzyme and substrate concns. As a consequence, a greater no. of substrates can be tolerated in a single assay, thus enabling an increase in the diversity space of the library. Sol. positional protease substrate libraries of 137,180 and 6859 members, possessing amino acid diversity at the P4-P3-P2-P1 and P4-P3-P2 positions, resp., were constructed. Employing this screening method, we profiled the substrate specificities of a diverse array of proteases, including the serine proteases thrombin, plasmin, factor Xa, urokinase-type plasminogen activator, tissue plasminogen activator, granzyme B, trypsin, chymotrypsin, human neutrophil elastase, and the cysteine proteases papain and cruzain. The resulting profiles create a pharmacophoric portrayal of the proteases to aid in the design of selective substrates and potent inhibitors.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Choe, Y.; Leonetti, F.; Greenbaum, D. C.; Lecaille, F.; Bogyo, M.; Brömme, D.; Ellman, J. A.; Craik, C. S. Substrate profiling of cysteine proteases using a combinatorial peptide library identifies functionally unique specificities. J. Biol. Chem. 2006, 281 (18), 12824– 12832,  DOI: 10.1074/jbc.M513331200
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      23
      Substrate Profiling of Cysteine Proteases Using a Combinatorial Peptide Library Identifies Functionally Unique Specificities
      Choe, Youngchool; Leonetti, Francesco; Greenbaum, Doron C.; Lecaille, Fabien; Bogyo, Matthew; Broemme, Dieter; Ellman, Jonathan A.; Craik, Charles S.
      Journal of Biological Chemistry (2006), 281 (18), 12824-12832CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
      The substrate specificities of papain-like cysteine proteases (clan CA, family C1) papain, bromelain, and human cathepsins L, V, K, S, F, B, and five proteases of parasitic origin were studied using a completely diversified positional scanning synthetic combinatorial library. A bifunctional coumarin fluorophore was used that facilitated synthesis of the library and individual peptide substrates. The library has a total of 160,000 tetrapeptide substrate sequences completely randomizing each of the P1, P2, P3, and P4 positions with 20 amino acids. A microtiter plate assay format permitted a rapid detn. of the specificity profile of each enzyme. Individual peptide substrates were then synthesized and tested for a quant. detn. of the specificity of the human cathepsins. Despite the conserved three-dimensional structure and similar substrate specificity of the enzymes studied, distinct amino acid preferences that differentiate each enzyme were identified. The specificities of cathepsins K and S partially match the cleavage site sequences in their physiol. substrates. Capitalizing on its unique preference for proline and glycine at the P2 and P3 positions, resp., selective substrates and a substrate-based inhibitor were developed for cathepsin K. A cluster anal. of the proteases based on the complete specificity profile provided a functional characterization distinct from std. sequence anal. This approach provides useful information for developing selective chem. probes to study protease-related pathologies and physiologies.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XjvFKktLY%253D&md5=8a90a92e810ac59436a9ea3a12536f27
    24. 24
      Thornberry, N. A.; Rano, T. A.; Peterson, E. P.; Rasper, D. M.; Timkey, T.; Garcia-Calvo, M.; Houtzager, V. M.; Nordstrom, P. A.; Roy, S.; Vaillancourt, J. P.; Chapman, K. T.; Nicholson, D. W. A combinatorial approach defines specificities of members of the caspase family and granzyme B: Functional relationships established for key mediators of apoptosis. J. Biol. Chem. 1997, 272 (29), 17907– 17911,  DOI: 10.1074/jbc.272.29.17907
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      24
      A combinatorial approach defines specificities of members of the caspase family and granzyme B. Functional relationships established for key mediators of apoptosis
      Thornberry, Nancy A.; Rano, Thomas A.; Peterson, Erin P.; Rasper, Dita M.; Timkey, Tracy; Garcia-Calvo, Margarita; Houtzager, Vicky M.; Nordstrom, Penny A.; Roy, Sophie; Vaillancourt, John P.; Chapman, Kevin T.; Nicholson, Donald W.
      Journal of Biological Chemistry (1997), 272 (29), 17907-17911CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
      There is compelling evidence that members of the caspase (interleukin-1β converting enzyme/CED-3) family of cysteine proteases and the cytotoxic lymphocyte-derived serine protease granzyme B play essential roles in mammalian apoptosis. Here we use a novel method employing a positional scanning substrate combinatorial library to rigorously define their individual specificities. The results divide these proteases into three distinct groups and suggest that several have redundant functions. The specificity of caspases 2, 3, and 7 and Caenorhabditis elegans CED-3 (DEXD) suggests that all of these enzymes function to incapacitate essential homeostatic pathways during the effector phase of apoptosis. In contrast, the optimal sequence for caspases 6, 8, and 9 and granzyme B ((I/L/V)EXD) resembles activation sites in effector caspase proenzymes, consistent with a role for these enzymes in upstream components in a proteolytic cascade that amplifies the death signal.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXkslKgtbc%253D&md5=44abe20ff00574bb756a1591ed77e110
    25. 25
      Poreba, M.; Salvesen, G. S.; Drag, M. Synthesis of a HyCoSuL peptide substrate library to dissect protease substrate specificity. Nat. Protoc. 2017, 12 (10), 2189– 2214,  DOI: 10.1038/nprot.2017.091
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      25
      Synthesis of a HyCoSuL peptide substrate library to dissect protease substrate specificity
      Poreba, Marcin; Salvesen, Guy S.; Drag, Marcin
      Nature Protocols (2017), 12 (10), 2189-2214CODEN: NPARDW; ISSN:1750-2799. (Nature Research)
      Many biol. and chem. based approaches have been developed to design highly active and selective protease substrates and probes. It is, however, difficult to find substrate sequences that are truly selective for any given protease, as different proteases can demonstrate a great deal of overlap in substrate specificities. In some cases, better enzyme selectivity can be achieved using peptide libraries contg. unnatural amino acids such as the hybrid combinatorial substrate library (HyCoSuL), which uses both natural and unnatural amino acids. HyCoSuL is a combinatorial library of tetrapeptides contg. amino acid mixts. at the P4-P2 positions, a fixed amino acid at the P1 position, and an ACC (7-amino-4-carbamoylmethylcoumarin) fluorescent tag occupying the P1' position. Once the peptide is recognized and cleaved by a protease, the ACC is released and produces a readable fluorescence signal. Here, we describe the synthesis and screening of HyCoSuL for human caspases and legumain. We also discuss possible modifications and adaptations of this approach that make it a useful tool for developing highly active and selective reagents for a wide variety of proteolytic enzymes. The protocol can be divided into three major parts: (i) solid-phase synthesis of the fluorescence-labeled HyCoSuL, (ii) screening of protease P4-P2 preferences, and (iii) synthesis of the optimized activity probes equipped with an AOMK (acyloxymethyl ketone) reactive group and a biotin label for easy detection. Beginning with the library design, the entire protocol can be completed in 4-8 wk (HyCoSuL synthesis: 3-5 wk; HyCoSuL screening per enzyme: 4-8 d; and activity-based probe synthesis: 1-2 wk).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhsFehtrjF&md5=5ece1429e76feedd3eb864f07da7f8b7
    26. 26
      Poreba, M.; Kasperkiewicz, P.; Snipas, S. J.; Fasci, D.; Salvesen, G. S.; Drag, M. Unnatural amino acids increase sensitivity and provide for the design of highly selective caspase substrates. Cell Death Differ. 2014, 21 (9), 1482– 1492,  DOI: 10.1038/cdd.2014.64
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      26
      Unnatural amino acids increase sensitivity and provide for the design of highly selective caspase substrates
      Poreba, M.; Kasperkiewicz, P.; Snipas, S. J.; Fasci, D.; Salvesen, G. S.; Drag, M.
      Cell Death & Differentiation (2014), 21 (9), 1482-1492CODEN: CDDIEK; ISSN:1350-9047. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Traditional combinatorial peptidyl substrate library approaches generally utilize natural amino acids, limiting the usefulness of this tool in generating selective substrates for proteases that share similar substrate specificity profiles. To address this limitation, we synthesized a Hybrid Combinatorial Substrate Library (HyCoSuL) with the general formula of Ac-P4-P3-P2-Asp-ACC, testing the approach on a family of closely related proteases - the human caspases. The power of this library for caspase discrimination extends far beyond traditional PS-SCL approach, as in addn. to 19 natural amino acids we also used 110 diverse unnatural amino acids that can more extensively explore the chem. space represented by caspase-active sites. Using this approach we identified and employed peptide-based substrates that provided excellent discrimination between individual caspases, allowing us to simultaneously resolve the individual contribution of the apical caspase-9 and the executioner caspase-3 and caspase-7 in the development of cytochrome-c-dependent apoptosis for the first time.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXot1ymsLs%253D&md5=319049bbe5679cb416e1698a900d2a47

      Salisbury, C. M.; Maly, D. J.; Ellman, J. A. Peptide microarrays for the determination of protease substrate specificity. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2002, 124 (50), 14868– 14870,  DOI: 10.1021/ja027477q
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      27
      Peptide Microarrays for the Determination of Protease Substrate Specificity
      Salisbury, Cleo M.; Maly, Dustin J.; Ellman, Jonathan A.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2002), 124 (50), 14868-14870CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A method is described for the prepn. of substrate microarrays that allow for the rapid detn. of protease substrate specificity. Peptidyl coumarin substrates, synthesized on solid support using std. techniques, are printed onto glass slides using DNA microarraying equipment. The linkage from the peptide to the slide is formed through a chemoselective reaction, resulting in an array of uniformly displayed fluorogenic substrates. The arrays can be treated with proteases to yield substrate specificity profiles. Std. instrumentation for visualization of microarrays can be used to obtain comparisons of the specificity consts. for all of the prepd. substrates. The utility of these arrays is demonstrated by the selective cleavage of preferred substrates with trypsin, thrombin, and granzyme B, and by assessing the extended substrate specificity of thrombin using a microarray of 361 different peptidyl coumarin substrates.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XovVChtr8%253D&md5=947f296baec5916ea2588d7b09c956b1
    28. 28
      Gosalia, D. N.; Salisbury, C. M.; Ellman, J. A.; Diamond, S. L. High throughput substrate specificity profiling of serine and cysteine proteases using solution-phase fluorogenic peptide microarrays. Mol. Cell. Proteomics 2005, 4 (5), 626– 636,  DOI: 10.1074/mcp.M500004-MCP200
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      28
      High throughput substrate specificity profiling of serine and cysteine proteases using solution-phase fluorogenic peptide microarrays
      Gosalia, Dhaval N.; Salisbury, Cleo M.; Ellman, Jonathan A.; Diamond, Scott L.
      Molecular and Cellular Proteomics (2005), 4 (5), 626-636CODEN: MCPOBS; ISSN:1535-9476. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
      Proteases regulate numerous biol. processes with a degree of specificity often dictated by the amino acid sequence of the substrate cleavage site. To map protease/substrate interactions, a 722-member library of fluorogenic protease substrates of the general format Ac-Ala-X-X-(Arg/Lys)-coumarin was synthesized (X = all natural amino acids except cysteine) and microarrayed with fluorescent calibration stds. in glycerol nanodroplets on glass slides. Specificities of 13 serine proteases (activated protein C, plasma kallikrein, factor VIIa, factor IXaβ, factor XIa and factor α XIIa, activated complement C1s, C1r, and D, tryptase, trypsin, subtilisin Carlsberg, and cathepsin G) and 11 papain-like cysteine proteases (cathepsin B, H, K, L, S, and V, rhodesain, papain, chymopapain, ficin, and stem bromelain) were obtained from 103,968 sep. microarray fluorogenic reactions (722 substrates × 24 different proteases × 6 replicates). This is the first comprehensive study to report the substrate specificity of rhodesain, a papain-like cysteine protease expressed by Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense, a parasitic protozoa responsible for causing sleeping sickness. Rhodesain displayed a strong P2 preference for Leu, Val, Phe, and Tyr in both the P1 = Lys and Arg libraries. Soln.-phase microarrays facilitate protease/substrate specificity profiling in a rapid manner with minimal peptide library or enzyme usage.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXktlSmsrY%253D&md5=f8560e365d168d1e8e0aa918dca621e9
